editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: ANNUS TENEBROSUS, OR THE DARK YEAR. Or Astrologicall Iudgements upon two Lunar Eclipses, and one admirable Eclips of the Sun, all visible in England, 1652.
Together with a short Method how to judge the effects of ECLIPSES.
A True Type of the Suns great Eclipse.

q.l: Quod priscis vetitum erat, quod{que} Parabolis
Vix olim licuit dicere; Nunc mihi

div.p: By WILLIAM LILLY, Student in Astrologie.
London, Printed for the Company of Stationers, and H. Blunden at the Castle in Corn-hill, 1652.

div.head: TO THE COMMON-WEALTH of ENGLAND, William Lilly, Student in Astrology, wisheth all Prosperity.

p.hi: GOd hath granted me to speak, and to conceive as is meet for the things that are given me, it is he that leadeth unto Wisedome, and directeth the wise.
God hath given me certain knowledge of things that are, to know how the world was made, and the Operation of the Elements.

div.p: The beginning, ending, and midst of the times, the alteration of the turning of the Sun, and the Change of seasons.

p.hi: The Circuits of years, and the Positions of Stars.

div.p: Thus Salomon in the seventh of Wisedom, ver. 15, 16, 17, 18, 19.

From the sence of these verses it may be inferred,
that the Science or knowledge of Astrology, or influences of Heaven are clearly intended, and the Art lawfull, else the wisest amongst mortall men, would not so significantly have mentioned the Positions of Stars: for no man can know the Operations and vertues of the Elements except by Astrology; and a Position, or figure of Heaven is needless, unless from thence a judgement be derived.

We do confess, that our self emits this present labour in a time wherein we find Astrology much spoken of, much preacht against, much labour taken to overthrow it for ever, root and branch; without distinction, or without an Audite Querelam of such persons as are therein versed. If our judgement doth vary from others, and that prove offensive, we know as able Divines for learning, yea, more grave, more experimentall in all manner of divinity and Sciences, were of a different judgement concerning the proceeds of this present Parliament, and from those of the late Synod, who first took part with this present State; Each maintained their opinions by Scripture, Reason, and Arguments yet there can be but one Truth, therefore one side or other of these Divines must of necessity have erred, and by their error have seduced many to Destruction.

Presbitery and Independency are not Twins in unity, more than Esau and Jacob; by what we have delivered, we onely say, severall men, severall opinions: and so it will be concerning Astrology; some maintaining its legality, others roaring, and denying it to be a lawfull Art. It shall be our labour to manifest
unto Posterity, that as learned Divines as ever lived in this world, have honourably esteem'd Astrology, studied and maintained its lawfulness; nay, those who have been in some places of their Works very bitter enemies unto it, have notwithstanding in other places, acknowledged as much as we desire.

Augustin who is so much vaunted of to be an enemy unto this Art, yet thought it no indignity to have knowledge in this Science; but at last concluded, hee would not have a man spend all his life-time in this study. Indeed had he done so, it had been a great loss unto the Church of God.

Albertus Magnus, Bishop of Ratisbon, whom most admire, and conceive a greater Clerk then Augustin, he saith; Quid desideratius concionatori quam habere eam scientiam quae doceat nos qualiter mundanorum ad hoc, & ad illud mutatio, celestium corporum fiat mutatione. And immediatly after; Universi ordinationem nulla scientia humana perfectè attingit, sicut Scientia judiciorum Astrorum.

What is more to be desired by any Preacher, than to know that Science which instructeth us how the change and alteration of worldly affairs come to be thus, or thus disposed by mutation of the Heavenly bodies.

No humane Science or learning doth perfectly attain the Ordination of the whole Universe; except the knowledge of the judgement of the Starres. Albertus Mag. tom. 5. pag. 659. Nos habemus unam Scientiam Mathematicam, que docet nos in rerum causis causationem causarum considerare. Wee have one
Mathematicall Science, which teacheth us to consider the causation of causes, in the causes of things.

Great are the outcrys, and very grievous the censures, wherwith the Ignorant or unknowing man doth at this time burthen Judiciall Astrology, and its harmless Professors. Whilst they doe suppose that we Christian Astrologers maintain a fatall necessity of all actions, or as if that God had prescribed good or evill, yea wicked actions unto man. Some of these opinions perhaps were held by Heathens, we profess in the fear of God that Christian Astrology renounces all such Atheisme. Nunquam vereundiores nos esse oportet, quam cum de futuris conjicimus, viz. Let us be modest in our Conjectures of Contingencies, Divines affirm Adam, Moses and Salomon well versed in Astrology, and Pineda lib. 3. de rebus Salomon: cap. 8. saith, illum judiciariam Astrologiam calluisse circa naturalia, circa inclinationes hominum, &c. That he well understood Judiciall Astrology concerning naturall things, and the inclinations of men. It was not the least honour done to Astrologers, that the first fruits of the Gentiles were men Scient in Astrology, who came to worship Christ in the Cradle.

Whereupon Gregory the Great sayes, Deus accōmodatè ad eorum scientiam docuit, ut qui in stellarum observatione versabantur, ex stellis Christum discerent, very fitly did God enable the knowledge of those wise men, that they should learn Christ from the Stars, who were versed in the observation of them. But ahlas, Dean Owen of Christ Church in
Oxford, will have Astrology to be Diabolicall: ipse Dixit.

I ran counter his judgment with the opinion of Panormitan an Abbot, an Abbot being an Ace above a Dean. Astrologia nec per jus Canonicum, nec per Civile est prohibita, nec est in se mala, cum sit una ex artibus liberalibus, & jura praemient has scientias excercentes. Modo non dicant Astrologi necessitari homines à corporibus Caelestibus.

Astrology is not prohibited either by the Cannon or Civill Law, nor in it self is evill, sith its one of the liberall Sciences, and men reward those exercising these Sciences; so that Astrologers maintain not, that men are necessitated to this or that from the Celestiall bodies, Panormitan super 5. Decret. de sorti legi Is.

Alii & alii planetae diversas complexiones & habitus & dispositiones in nobis constituunt. Damascen. lib. 2. cap. 7. These and these Planets doe cause or constitute divers complexions, habits and dispositions in us.

I forbear the opinion and high esteem Master Gregory, and my Countryman Burton (men of singular learning) had of Astrology, both these of Dean Owens Colledge, but these were profound Schollers. Next Mr. Nye, also, a subtill man, he will have Astrology Diabolicall; Ile answer him with the opinion of Causinus a Jesuit, who saith, Certissimum est, corpora Caelestia in haec inferiora agere non secus ac Sol & Luna, quorum mirabiles effectus in universa, quotidie natura experimur: It is most certain, the heavenly bodies have influence on our inferior
bodies, even as the Sun and Moon, whose wonderfull effects upon the whole Universe, we daily find by experience. Where the Question is not Controversiall, I hold a Papists judgment as good and sound as a Protestants. Nay, I will produce a Saint, viz. Thomas Aquinas 1 part. q. 115. Who confesseth: Astrologos in pluribus posse non falsa praedicere, maximè quidem in Communi, quia plures hominum sequuntur passiones, ad quas cooperari possunt corpora Caelestia. &c. Astrologers in many things erre not, chiefly in generall matters, because most men follow their passions, unto which the heavenly bodies cooperate, Zanchius we know is in high esteem with all Protestants, and in some things is against Astrology: treating thereof he makes two questions.
1. An aliqua futurarum rerum ex astris praesensio ac Divinatio haberi possit, viz. If any foreknowledge or Divination could bee had of future events from the Stars: himself resolves it thus.

Nemini enim dubium esse credo, aliquam aliquarum futurarum rerum praesensionem, eamque veram ex astris, seu ex Coelorum influxibus observatis haberi posse: quandoquidem & Medici ex praecognita futura Lunae mutatione, & ex novi-Lunio, ex pleni-Lunio, &c. Verè & certò praedicunt corporum aegrotantium alterationes, morborum incrementa, pericula mortis aegrotantibus imminere. Et navium gubernatores ex notatis astris, certò praedicunt ventorum mutationes, maris aestus & alia quam plurima. I beleeve no man doubts, but that there is some prescience of some future matters, to
be made, and that very certain and true from the Starres, and the experimented influxes of the Heavens: wee know Phisitians from the foreknowledge of the Moons Mutation, viz. New and full Moon do TRULY and CERTANLY, foretell the alterations of sick bodyes, the increases of Diseases, & when perill of Death is at hand to the sick.
All this while Zanchius sayth not, Astrology is Diabolicall.
And again, Voluntas non regenita quandam habet connexionem cum Coelis, quatenus scilicet carnales affectiones, &c.
Corporum autem qualitates à coelorum influxibus non parum dependent, &c.
Voluntas non renata quodam modo in suis actionibus à coelorum influxibus movetur, &c.

Quaedam verò sunt, quae certam & plerun{que} necessariam cum coelis & astris habent connexionem, uti sunt res, actiones{que} omnes in mundo, quae nullo pacto à voluntate proficiscuntur, ver. gra. aut sterilitas aut fertilitas terrae aëris perturbationes, pestis, elementorum commotiones, terrae motus, & alia id genus. Haec enim ex caelestibus influxibus & elementorum quae vi syderum aguntur, commotione, magna ex parte eveniunt: ideoque cum astris certam & plerumque necessariam habent connexionem, dico plerumque; quoniam aliquando etiam immediatè à Deo haec immittuntur, citra caelorum influxum ut patet in Scripturis; In English thus: The Will which is not new born, hath a certain connexion with the heavens, even as our Carnall affections have;
For the qualities of bodyes doe not a little depend from the influence of the Heavens.
The unregenerate Will is after a manner moved in its actions, by the influence of the Starrs.

Some other things there are, which have a certain, and for the most part necessary connexion with the heavens and starres, which no manner of wayes are derived from the Will, viz. Dearth or Plenty, perturbations of the ayr, the Plague, Commotions of the Elements, Earthquakes, &c. All these things doe come to pass, for the most part, from the heavenly influences, and of the Elements which are moved by force and vertue of the Starres, and therefore these have a certain Commotion, and for the most part necessary Connexion with the starres, I say mostly, for sometimes God doth such things immediatly without influxes.

You shall hear what Scotus in his 2. Sent. dist. 4. Astra inclinant voluntatem, in nullo tamen necessitatur. Accidit tamen frequenter Astrologos vera prognosticare de moribus hominum, propter pronitatem eorum, ad sequendum appetitivum sensitivum.

The Starrs incline the Will, but in no wise necessitate it, Frequently it comes to pass that Astrologers foretell • ruths concerning the manner of men, by reason of their proneness to follow their sensitive appetite.

Again, in lib. secund. de generat. Hoc modo etiam innotescit, quod qui sciret virtutem signorum, & stellarum in eis positarum dum nascitur res aliqua, posset prognosticari de tota vita rei generatae, licet hoc necessitatem non poneret, quia posset impediri per accidens.
By this means it comes to pass, that he who knows the vertues of the Signes and the Planets therein placed, may foretell (if he know when any creature is born) of the whole life of it. So far Scotus.

Videmus enim effectus multos hic in terra quorum causas ignoramus: beneficio autem verae Astrologiae causam suam at originē supra nos in Coelis habere cognoscimus. Zanchius, 118. De astrono. Wee see many effects hear on Earth, whose causes we are ignorant of, yet by benefit of True Astrologie, wee know they have a cause and production above us in the Heavens.

Nemo non videt pluvias grandines, nives, maris fluxum & refluxum, ventorum strepitus; sed nemo nisi qui adjutus est beneficio Astrologiae causas eorum in natura positas esse intelligit. Rains, hayls, snows, ebbing and flowing of the Seas, tempestious winds, no man but by help of Astrology can know these, who only understand the causes of these things are in nature. Hic ergo est usus verae astrologiae, ut multorum effectuum qui in terris fiunt causas quae in coelo sunt, agnoscat: aliquando etiam antequam fiunt, ipsos effectus in suis causis praevideat.

p.hi: Versatur igitur vera Astrologia circa corpora celestia & naturales illos effectus qui in corporibus terrenis ex corporum celestium influxu verè & naturaliter fiunt: habet hoc fundamentum prorsus verum: omnia terrena corpora, seu omnia inferiora corpora à coelestibus & superioribus corporibus aliquo modo regi, Zanchius 119. De Astronomia.

div.p:
This is therefore the use of true Astrology, to understand
from it, the causes which onely are in Heaven, of many effects which are on Earth; and sometimes long before they come to pass, that we may prevent the effec • s themselves in their causes.

True Astrology therefore is conversant about the heavenly bodyes, and their naturall effects, which have operation upon Earthly bodyes from the influence of the Heavenly, truly and naturally; this hath a Foundation very true and certain, that all Earthly bodyes, and all inferiour things, in some measure are ordered and disposed by the superiour Celestiall bodyes.
I will conclude with Peter Molin, cap. 7. pag. 158. who in 1640. Dedicated his Book De praecognitione, to the Dean and Chapter of Canterbury.

p.hi: Astrorum quidem est quaedam vis in animos hominum quatenus afficiunt elementa, & per elementa, humores corporum: qui quidem sunt irritamenta appetituum sed non afferunt voluntati ullam necessitatem.

div.p:
There is certainly a kind of force or vertue in the Starrs in the minds of men, so farre as the Elements affect them, and by the Elements the humours of bodyes are affected; which verily are the stirrers up of the appetites; but these produce not a necessity unto the will: If any Astrologer maintain a fatall necessity, or that the Will is compelled by influence of the Stars, we abhorre his opinion; for we are Christians, and though all Divines urge that point most, there was yet never any one of them produced any one Astrologer who maintained fatality; all that ever was objected was onely this piece of a verse of Manilius;
Certa stant omnia lege.
This man living in Augustus time, and being an Heathen and a Poet, might perhaps mean somewhat else than what is urged against Astrology, but again to Molineus.
Non est negandum (saith he) & caelestia vel aëria ostenta sepe fuisse prenuntia Calamitatum.
Wee may not deny but that Celestiall or Aëriall prodigies are many times the messengers of Calamity.

p.hi: Nec est quisqam nisi cujus animus ab religione plane ob rutuit, qui ad fulmina & fragorem tonitruum aut cruenti Cometae aspectum non tangatur metu. Cometem qui dicitur Xiphias portendere bella, experimentis comprobatum est, Pogoniam presignificare mortem regum. Quam ominosa fuerit stella crinita 1607. testantur tot calamitates urbium, Ecclesiarum projecta Cadavera, 160. pag. Petri Molinei.

div.p: Nor is there any, unlesse such a one who hath no Religion, who is not affrighted at lightning, and crashing of thunder, and the sight of an horrible Comet. A Comet like a Sword, wee find by experience signifies War. A Comet with a Beard portends the death of Kings: How ominous that blazing Star in 16 • 7. was, so many calamities of Cities, and desolation of Churches well testifies.
Three severall places of Scripture are produced against us; first, the 18. Deut. 10. verse.

p.hi:
There shall not be found amongst you, that maketh his Son or his Daughter to passe through the
fire, or that useth Divination, or an observer of times, or an inchanter, or a witch.

div.p: Causinus on these words saith thus: Nimis favent judiciariis qui tam infirmis rationibus impugnant. Ubi eum in toto hoc textu sugillantur, &c.
Ex quibus constat eos qui tam divinationem exercerint fuisse magos turpes & obscenos, qui nihil cum Astrologis commune habuerunt, &c.
The 47. of Esay is urged verse 13. Let now the Astrologers, the Star-gazers and monthly Prognosticators stand up and save them.

This whole Chapter is against the Babilonians, who despising God, and treading his people under foot, were wholly given to superstitious curiosities, and whereas God had determined and said by his Prophets they should come to destruction, these superstitious Astrologers, did warrant the contrary; Can the arme of flesh contend with God, or the creature with the Creator; we abhor such things, those Astrologers were worthily punished, and so let them be who act such things; yet here is only the abuse not the Art prohibited, no more than in those many places of Scripture where God rebukes the Priests: yet they continued them in those times, and wee continue them to this day, they ever were turbulent.

Jeremy 10. verse 2. Bee not dismayed at the Signs of Heaven. What can bee infer'd from heaven, but, that the Godly and faithfull who have Divine protection, ought not to fear the Signs or Prodigies of heaven as the Heathen did; what is this unto Astrology, those words neither make it lawfull or unlawfull, or are for it or against it, though Master
Gattaker fruitlesly spends a whole side of paper upon these words in his Annotations: but he shall ere long have the judgments of abler Divines than himself and to better purpose on that 2 verse of Jeremy. Chap. 10. You shall hear the exposition of a reverend Minister on this place, equall in years to Mr. Gataker; and in true Divinity and knowledge of the Orientall tongues, far surmounting him, his word are th • se.

The scope and drift of the Prophets word is, that the People of Israel should not so stand in awe of the signs of heaven, as the heathen were. For many of the heathen looked no higher than the Firmament. They considered not, that there is an eternall Almighty God ruling over all. God denounced to the Israelites, that for their Transgressions, He would make the h • aven over their head to be brasse, and the earth under them to be iron. He would change Natures course, according to his holy and righteous pleasure. And whereas he will doe so sometimes, His people are not so to feare the Judgements signified in the heaven as doe the Heathen, which know not the God of Israel, as if there were no way to escape them.

Who concludes his Answer with Osianders words on the Text: Ne discatis impietatem gentium, quoe non modo meteora inusitata, & morus syderum observant, atque ex iis de futuris eventibus pronunciant, ve um etiam ita metuunt à constellationibus, ut earum effectus evitare non posse existiment. Haec enim Gentium est impietas, nec populum Dei decet. Non damnatur Astrologia pura, (quae nihil habet de magia) si modo quis Astrologicas praedictiones pro conjecturis, non autem pro vaticiniis certis habeat.

Learn not the impiety of the Heathens; who did not only observe unusuall meteors and the motions of the Stars, and determined thereby of future Events, but were also so terrified by those Constellations, that they thought it impossible to shun their effects. This was the wickednesse of the Gentiles, nor doth it become the people of God so to doe.
Yet hereby pure Astrology is not condemned (so it medles not with unlawfull Magique) or so that it deliver its Astrologicall Predictions for Conjectures, and not maintain them Oraculous or positive.

We hope now we shall aboundantly satisfie the whole Nation, by the Judgements of such Godly men, whose opinions we have related in our Epistle, and that the people will beleeve Astrologers to be Christians, and Astrology a lawfull Art, notwithstanding the senseless and scandalous Invectives, corrupt and spurious Expositions daily and weekly delivered by a perverse Generation of men falsly called Divines.

Wee conclude with our humble submission to the high Court of Parliament, resolving a full obedience to what Acts shall from thence proceed, either for our encouragement or discouragement, or further progress in Astrology, which is so Divine of it self, so usefull for man, and in these last and worst of times was not a little serviceable unto this Common-wealth.

div.head: ANNƲS TENEBROSƲS, OR The Dark Year, 1652. An Astrologicall Discourse concerning the effects of two Lunar ECLIPSES, and one formidable one of the SUNNE in this YEAR 1652.
div.p:
IT was as wisely as truely observed by the learned Historian Thucydides, that, some yeares before those three and twenty years Peloponensian Warres of the miserable Greekes amongst themselves, wherein every City or Commonwealth of Greece was in one kinde or other ingaged, That those things which in former times there went onely a fame of, though rarely in fact confirmed, were then made credible by the ensuing bloody Warres of the Grecians one with another. The forerunners of which Quarrels he saith were these; Earthquakes generall to the greatest part of the World, Thucydides, bi. 1. pag. 14.
and most violent withall. Eclipses of the Sunne oftner then is reported of any former time, great droughts, &c.

If we in Europe, or many Kingdomes, People and Nations herein
are hastening unto such disastrous times and accidents as our Author delivers unto Posterity then to have happened, Let God be glorified, who hath not been wanting in these worst of dayes and times by many signall Prodigies so opportunely seene and felt by many men in severall Countries, to admonish and forewarne even us English, as well as many other Kingdomes and Nations what he intends suddenly to doe. Very many and admirable have beene the Prodigies, which of late yeares have appeared in the Dominions of the King of Spain; Insurrection in Naples 1647. as first that never to be parallel'd uproar and Tumult of the People in Naples in July 1647. at what time they made Masaniello a poore Fisherman their Captain Generall, who for some dayes, had the clearest and absolutest Command over the People, that ever any History mentions, as it is excellently set forth in two little Treatises by the delicate Pen of James Howell, Esq.

Another as remarkable a Prodigie lately happened in one of the Countries belonging to the King of Spain, viz. at Bilbo in Biscay, Inundation waters at Bilbo▪ where there was so great an Inundation of Waters, August 1651. by reason of a continuall Raine for almost twenty one dayes; during which time the Waters were poured downe from the Mountaines with such violence, and so mightily increased, that the Waters came sixteen foot high into the very Towne, to the very great prejudice and dammage of al the stranger Merchants and Inhabitants. We had the Story thereof in Print, but my selfe had it from the relation of Master N. Master of an English Ship, and at that time there. Since which time an English Merchant there resident, affirmed unto me, that had it not beene for a great strong Church, which partly broke the violence of the Waters as they came down from the Hils, he conceived the Waters would have over-thrown the whole Towne: It is judged three Millions will not repaire the losse that both the Towne and Merchants suffered; and what seemes most Miraculous, is, that one mile below the Towne, the ordinary Channell seemed to swell nothing at all with that great aboundance of water which so impetuously tore up
the very Pavements of Stone in the streets, in some places a yard deepe or more. What a fearfull irruption of Waters there happened at Amsterdam about January or February 1650. we all remember, and that People have cause to Lament.

These prodigious Tumults, and more then ordinary swellings of the Sea-bankes, and furious Inundations of Waters are most assured Messengers of Gods wrath and anger unto Mankinde; we all know the Ʋniversall Deluge and almost whole drowning of all Mankinde did immediately succeed after the Cataracts of Heaven were let loose; you shall onely hear the opinion of two or three learned Authors what is the naturall signification of such extraordinary effl • xions of Waters, or other excursion of any one of the Elements. Inundationes maris ac fluminum cum fuerint praeter naturam, populorum & gentium hostilium adventum praenuntiant; si obruant agres, Cardanus, lib. 14. devarietat. pag 703.
depraedabuntur finitima, & agros ipsos, si maenia sternant, dirum est. The overflowings of the Sea or of Rivers, when they exceed the ordinary course of nature, doe foretell the comming in or an inrode of People and Strangers, Enemies, into those parts. If these Inundations doe over-whelme the Fields or Pastures, then the bordering places shall be invaded, yea and the Fields themselves; if they levell those Bankes, it is ominous. Multitudo quoque aquarum generaliter morbos portendit, ut etiam medici affirmant. A multitude of Wat • rs generally betokens Diseases. De aquarum inundationibus atque effluxibus, nota est vox sacrarum literarum. Aquae multae Populi multi. Concerning the inundations and over-flowings of Waters, it is well known what the letter of Scripture saith, Many Waters, many People. Salvum me fac Deus, inquit David, quoniam aquae ingressae sunt usque ad animam meam. Save me, O God, saith David, because the waters are even entred into my soule. He implies hereby himselfe almost over-pressed by a multitude of enemies. Nec effusas unquam impunè intumuisse aquas, Peucerus de Meteorologia, page 338.
aut frustra ventes insolentiore tumultu increpitasse, suis nullae non gentes experimentis, moxque insecutis cladibus didicerunt, etiam nostra, imo recentissima memoria, incursionibus peregrinorum excercituum, direptionihus, incendiis, coede vastatis omnibus.

Nor have the Waters or Seas at any time to no purpose thus swelled or overflowed their Bankes, or the Windes so impetuously or boysterously roared; very few are the People or Nations where such horrible and unusuall Irruptions have appeared,Note. but they have learned by wofull Experience, that not many yeares after these outragious Swellings the People of that Nation where these were, have miserably smarted with immediate succeeding mischiefs, viz. Either the incursions of Strangers Forces, Armies, or the like, into their Countries; or else a great decay, consumption or wasting of their Men, together with bloodshed and other wofull calamities concomitant. Of which Prodigious irruption then happening, and some Aeriall fights or Prodi • ies lately seene in the States Dominions, I meane in the Hollanders, that prudentiall People will, I hope take speciall notice, it concerning both Holland and Zealand so to doe, and in a greater measure the Rulers or Governors of those Provinces, Townes or Cities therein seated: For, Inundatio res est sinistra, malique ominis. These Inundations are il signes, and portend no good unto them. Particulares enim excessus elementorum irae divinae sunt quaedam praecipua instrumenta, quod se vi summa atque praecipiti effundunt latius. The particular excesses of the Elements, are certaine principall Engins of Divine vengeance, in regard they extend themselvs with so much force & so great violence more then ordinary. All Philosophers unanimously consenting in this; that, Elementorum praedominia vel insignis alicujus inter primas qualitates excessus aut vitia, promiscuè sequitur aliud flagelli genus, quo mortalium plurimi perierunt; sames scilicet ac memoranda sterilitas. Cornelius Gemma de Naturae divinis Caracterismis, pag. 170.

The Masteries or over-powring of the Elements, or any famous or unusuall extravagancies or excesses of any of them amongst themselves or their first qualities, doe manifest, that not long after promiscuously there followes a kind of Scourge, whereby many People are consumed; and this is usually Famine or some remarkable Barrennesse of the Earth. The overflowing of the watery Element hath ever beene reputed Prodigious unto the People where it happened.Let Amsterdam beware. Aquarum
vero irruptio potius ad vulgus ignobile spectat; agunt enim aquae multitudine & impetu: Aquarum gurges inevitabilis, qui nullis objicibus, nulla vel arte deinceps vel violentia coercetur, quin pariter omnia, permistis inter se arenis, saxis, cinere, fumo, igne & aqua, in Chaos teterrimum prolabuntur, Gemma 180.

The irruption, overflowing or breaking forth of Waters most concernes the common People or ignoble person; for Waters doe work with fiercenesse and violence: The Whirlpoole or violence of Waters is inevitable, nor is its force or whirling restrained or kept in by any Gin or Device of Art; but all alike, and together both Sands, Stone, Gravell, Cinders, What the States of Holland may expect from their People. Smoake or Vapour are all gathered together into a most horrible Chaos; intimating hereby, that such like watery Prodigies, doe declare an unruly Multitude and giddy People, that would willingly let loose the raines of Government, and become disobedient unto Authority, though in the end it turne unto their owne Confusion, and also Destruction of all those who participate with them in their folly and Councell. Igitur si laxato naturae Nodo, convulsisque claustris extra suos limites aquae proferantur, & effraeni violentiae impetu terram peragrent, non id temerè fortuitoque, sed divino fit imperio: tum ut gravem puniendis hominum sceleribus stragem edant: tum ut in posterum arma hostium, & intestinos praecipuè factionum motus, pest • mque & famem terris ingruentem praenuntient, Eden Nehusus lib. 20. pag. 180.

If therefore the chaine of Nature be unloosed, and the enclosures of Waters pluckt up, so that they get forth of their owne proper Channels or Bounds, and overflow the Earth or ground with a lawlesse mastery of violence; this is not done by Fortune or chance, but it comes to passe by Divine command. That People may be as well sensible of some fearfull slaughters at hand for punishing the wretchednesse of men, as of Factions, intestine Divisions, Armies of Enemies, a Plague and Famine to be approaching, &c. But of this enough.

Let us come neerer home; for the most of what hath yet beene delivered concernes the Spaniard and Dutch, and in
some measure the French. And although we in our ensuing Discourse, intended at first onely a discovery of the naturall significations of three Eclipses in this yeare 1652. yet occasionally let me leave this Memorandum unto Posterity, of some Prodigies which our Nation are fully satisfied to have beene seene in England; we cannot deny but that in every of the years 1644. 1645. 1646. 1647. in severall Counties of England there were more frequently then in former times seene Parelia or Mock suns, or Paraselenes or Mock-Moones, besides two dayes before that fatall Fight at Marston Moore in Yorkshire, July 1644. our selves and thousands more beheld strange apparitions, clashings, fightings in the Ayre from about eight or nine of clock at night until about eleven or twelve, with monstrous shapes in the Ayre and strange Hiatus gapings or openings of the Clouds.Rigel, Apho. 87.
Signa quae videntur in coelo, quae apparuerint extra motum & cursum naturae, nunquam eveniunt sine magna mutatione Regnorum illius climatis in quo apparuerint. Two dayes after these apparitions Don Rupert was routed at Marston in Yorkshire.
Signes or apparitions which are seen in Heaven, and doe appeare without motion and against the course of nature, such Prodigies as these never appeare unto Men without a great change or Mutation of the Kingdomes of that climate in which they were visible.

p.hi: Plures soles ferè visos constat, cum nova essent foedera consuta, aut structae adornataeque conspirationes,
vel ad rapienda imperia, vel eos qui praesederint de fastigio dejicendos: aut omnino, nisi aliqui res novas molirentur, à quibus impenderent innovationes turbationésque etiam in Religione.

div.p: Its manifest, many Suns are then seene, when new Leagues should be patcht up, and specious conspiracies layd or designed,No Prodigy but hath some signification as unto the Religious. either to bereave some of their Dominions, or to pull downe some Great ones, who then doe governe with scorne and disgrace; either such things happen altogether, or else there is much disturbance and innovation in Religion or things Divine. That such like accidents have succeeded in England of late, and in Scotland and Ireland, no Criticke dares deny it: I could verifie Peucers words by examples drawne from other Countries.
The third Eclips of the Moon will be visible the seventh day of September, the Digits there eclipsed will be neare ten.

The magnitude of these Eclipses, and the many great actions likely to succeed after them, will occasion Admiration all over Europe; and therefore I conceive Eickstadius when he came to give the calculation of them in his Ephemerides, breakes out into these words: Propter infrequentiam formidandae: These Eclipses (saith he) for their infrequency are much to be feared. And indeed the effects hereof, or from hence, will be formidable; which onely, besides some private requests, have occasioned our pen to assume both liberty to write, and freedome of our sence in its own expression, that we might thereby largely expatiate our thoughts having so copious but very unfrequent an Argument for our Basis; verily, it was long ere we were willing to assume this labour, which we declined untill towards the beginning of February; but then not knowing of any other Pen which would undertake the burthen or tediousnesse of the subject, we at last mustered up our forces, and at such spare houres as we gained from our daily imployment, have produced the Treatise ensuing; for Providence hath already brought us on the Stage of this World, and made us sensible that many of our Endevours formerly published have received a candid and gratefull acceptance amongst the learned in all
parts of Europe,
A scandalous exposition on the second ver. of the 10. Chapt. of Ieremiah by T. G, hinting in expresse termes the Author of this Discours; but, Senes bis pucri.
The Author begins from a certain Epoche
notwithstanding the Malevolent Detractions of Home-borne Antagonists, who have both lost their Oyle and reputation, by endeavoring a confutation of what they understood not, having over-lookt our Labours with uncircumcised affections and Presbyterian Charity, most absurdly abusing their better time in Criticismes and fruitlesse Expositions on Texts of Scripture, against the whole current of Antiquity, Reason and very genuine sence of the Words themselves.

But that we may begin our worke from some certaine Epoche of Time, and not involve our selves into a laborinth of unnecessary Inquiries, we are to consider that, Nullus effectus sive parvus à Revolutione vel ab aliis significantibus erit, quod non primum a Radice habeat Exordium: Ludovicus de Rigiis, Aphoris. 51. Quare summa diligentia radices considerandae sunt; viz. There is no effect or materiall accident, no matter though it seeme small, which is signified either in a Revolution or otherwise, which first of all had not a Beginning from some Radix; therefore with great diligence, the first Roots or foundations of things are to be inquired into.

♂ ♄ & ♃ 1603.In our Inquirie we finde that in the yeare 1603. and the seventh of December, there was a Mutation of the two superior or Planets, Saturne and Jupiter out of the watery Triplicitie into the Fiery Trigon. Fiery Trigon. Saturnus & Jupiter mutant res & convertunt, eritque variationis initium cum mutantur de una triplicitate ad aliam in conjunctionibus, & ex una figura in aliam. Rigel. Apho. 127. Cardanus will have us beleeve that there are very many means and wayes in Astrology whereby we may give judgment of the great Mutations contingent in this World; but out Author tels us, That Saturne and Jupiter doe change and overturne many humain affaires in this World, and that then or near that time there is first an appearance of them, when Jupiter and Saturn doe change from one Triplicity into another in their meetings or conjunctions, or from one Figure or Forme unto another. Saturn and Jupiter had continued very neare two hundred years in, the watery Triplicity, but now they have left that Trigon, and will continue as long in the fiery: as water and fire are contraries, so will the
Actions of these almost 180. yeers yet to come, be quite averse to what was then and in those times acted; and that is most rationall, and of especiall concernment for such as will hereafter wade into these mysteries: the same things are directed by Cardanus, that subtil Philosopher, in his first Sect. Apho. 64. Considerare oportet Conjunctiones magnas, medias & minores, tum Luminarium, atque etiam mutationes Planetarum tardigradorum in Signis, congressusque ad fixas pro temporum mutationibus.

We ought to consider in our judgements the Great, These are intended of ♄ ♃ and ♂, of which you may read copiously in our Propheticall Merlin, printed 1644. 1603. Means or Middle and Minor Conjunctions, as also the Conjunctions of the two Luminaries, together with the Mutations of the superior Planets who are of slow motion, their congresse to the fixed Starres; for these shew the variation and alteration of Times. At that moment of time when the preceding Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter was celebrated, and had their first entrance into the fiery Trigon, the ninteenth degree of ♎ did culminate; and in that very degree 1605. there was an Eclips of the Sun the second of Octob. in the afternoone, the digits Eclipsed being ten. What English man remembers not the Powder plot Powder-Plot. which was to have beene executed the fift of Novemb. following, for the Eclips in 1605. was in partill conjunction with the degree Culminating at the Coition of the two superiors; the intention of those Traytors and unadvised men being evidently apparant to root up Authority, viz. King, Lords and Commons, who are represented unto us from the tenth House: which horrible Action and to be admired Accident happening so soone after the Change of Saturn and Jupiter into the fiery Trigon, cals unto my memory and seemes to confirme what Leovitius the Bohemian wrote 1564.Of ♄ and ♃ their entrance into the fiery Trygon 1603 vnto the Emperor concerning the probability of those actions which were likely to happen upon the change of the two superiors out of the watery into the fiery Trigon; his words are these; Cum ergo nunc novus Trigonus impendeat qui igneus est, haud dubiè nova secula sequentur quae repentinas & violentas mutationes inducent. Seeing now there is a new Trigon at hand which is the fiery Trigon, without doubt new ages shall
follow, which shall produce sudden, rash and violent changes in the world.King James his coming into England. The Earle of Northumberl. a man of great spirit, would have had King Jam • s come in upon terms Let one example serve instead of many. That yeare viz. 1603. James King of Scotland, peaceably became King of England, but he might thanke a Cowardly ignoble Nobility for it, who then ruled the rost; old Northumberland was of another opinion, being a neer neighbour to the Scot; he knew their Treacheries and Beggeries. There were many eminent mutations upon this grand change of the Planets all over Europe neer those times in the beginning of this fiery Trigon; in truth we are in this Age (and so must be some Ages succeeding) under the dominion of this fiery Trigon; and ther fore it is no wonder to me, to see or hear every moment of so great alterations in the Kingdoms and Common-wealths of Europe; ever and anon we must expect such sudden changes in these our times, as no Age in former time could parallel; and these sharp and bitter Contentions are assuredly to have their beginning from Religious pretences, or breach of Customes: but alas, Religion in many is but the Foyl; Self-ends, next to the decrees of Providence, being the only Incendiary, and sole cause in every Mutation; one arme of flesh pulling down another, and thus it will be as long as Priests have any hand in temporal affairs or Councels.

These things we have handled occasionally; but seeing an Eclipse in Aries is intended for the subject matter of our Discourse, let us review Antiquity and its monuments, and
thereby we shall discover what were those mutations, what those Catastrophes which formerly were concomitant upon either Solar or Lunar Eclipse in Aries.
In anno Dom. 1418, there was an Eclipse in Aries, viz. 26. degrees, and 6. day of April.

And the yeer following, viz. 1419. the 26. day of March, Leovitius, de magnis Conjunct • onibus. there was another Eclipse, (satis tetra, saith mine Au • hor) a very horrible and great one; after which, Tumults in Bohemia succeeded, and many other strange accidents, as the learned and industrious Citizen of London Master Isackson relates in his Chronology, called Saturni Ephemerides,
Isackson the Londoner a painful Historiographer. unto whom I refer the Reader.

In the yeer 1485. an Eclipse of the Sun was in the 6. degree of Aries, Quae multa cumulavit mala, saith Leovitius, which stirred up by its sharp influence much wickednesse and many evils Untill 1530. and the 29. of March, the very same day our great Eclipse 1652. fals on: I say, that day in the 19. of Aries, there was a great Eclipse, Gubernatore ejus Marte, constituto propè oculum Tauri, stellam fixam violentam ac fervidam; viz. The Governour of that Eclipse was Mars, The Buls eye a violent fixed star. and he in Gemini, neer that violent and furious star called the Buls eye, which is a fixed star, hot, violent, fierce, and of evill influence: Behold what succeeded;God defend our Governours, its possible some clandestine designe is hatching by such men, and thereby they may run into a praemunire. He promiseth to write the Authors life. ☉ eclipsed in 29. ♈. Then did the noble City of Florence learn subjection, the Clergy of England did then run into a praemunire; for no premonition will incline these people to subjection; & hoc est certum & probatum per Kit Love, and his dear Brethren and Fellow-Petitioners: Not a treason can be managed without a Priest; but how Leonard Cook of Islington came to be one of that Fraternity of Petitioners, I much wonder, he being ab Infantia, homo rudis, Agrestisque & minimi ingenii.

We draw neerer unto the present times, in anno 1567. and 9. of April, there was an Eclips of Sol in 29. degr. of Aries, and this obscuration of Sol so great, that Leovitius cryed out, Profectò tam tetram ac horrendam Eclipsin Solis ab anno Dom. 1544. non habuimus, nec etiam multis futuris saeculis habituri sumus. Verily such a terrible and horrid Eclipse of the Sun we
have not had, saith our Author, since 1544. nor in many Ages succeeding shall have the like: whereupon he bursts out into these words, Mihi summi Magistratus periculum exilii aut captivitatis ostendi videtur.

In my judgement (quoth he) here is intended either the banishment of some great Prince or Governour, or some wofull calamity unto the Magistracy. Like presidents produce like actions, and like examples may happen to severall Magistrates in Europe upon the influence of our present great Eclipse.A Scottish King murthered about 1567. At that time you shall finde a Scotch King murthered, a matter of no great moment in Scotland; God grant those whom our Commonwealth shall send over into Scotland for Governours, be not served so really; such a thing I fear will be endeavoured; for once a Scot, and ever a Scot: The Hollander (for under them and there,Upon a former eclips in ♈ the Hollanders molested. I intend the Ʋnited Provinces) was extreamly afflicted by the Spaniard, the Duke of Alva then entring those Countryes, and building that magnificent Cittadell at Antwerp, to bridle that wealthy City. If the present Hollander urge their Neighbour Nations too far, they may happily taste the force of another Forreigner, no lesse powerfull then Alva, and be made sensible of an Invasion to better purpose then that of Alva.

From the yeer 1567. untill 1614. there was no conspicuous or memorable Eclipse in the Sign Aries, but then in 1614 there was one of the Sun in 19. degr. and 9. min. of Aries, but it was not visible in our Horizon, and so not in our Cognizance.

In 1633. there was a moderate Eclipse in 18. degr. and 21. min. of Aries, the digits eclipsed onely five, although a petty eclipse, yet being in Aries, the effects which attended it were many and memorable, both in England and Germany; neer unto that time you will finde wofull calamities to be stirring in Germany, and the people in England generally inclining to dislike of the Kings actions and Councels, matters, things; Councels then drawing unto maturity both in England and Scotland.

div.head:
Of the first ECLIPSE of the MOON, visible in ENGLAND the 15. of March, being Munday 1651/2. at 4. of the clock 4. min. A. M.
astrological chart
div.p:
WE find in the beginning of this Eclipse, the Luminary eclipsed, viz. the Moon, to be descending from the ninth house, hastening into the eighth, in which she is untill almost her greatest obscuration; towards, or at the end
of her eclipse, she fals even to the cusp of the seventh, and so under the Earth. If from thence we inferre this rationall Judgement, That there is a People yet in being, and they pretending unto Godlinesse or Religion, which men we in our plaine English doe call Divines, Ministers, Preachers, Ecclesiasticall Men,Probable Actions to ensue after this Eclips. or men conversant in holy things; in foraigne parts they are called Bishops, Cardinals, Abbots, Munks, Friers &c. Men that step up sometimes into Pulpits, and pretend to instruct our Soules with the Doctrine of Christanity, but obedience to their owne Constitutions; I say, if from hence we deliver this probable Judgement; That there are yet left a generation of such Men, who are now privately designing some future trouble unto our State and those Commonwealths where otherwise they reside, which will againe occasion the drawing of blood unto our State and other Nations, and destruction unto themselves, viz. Ministery and Munkeries, and unto as many of their abused Disciples and Proselytes, as shall suffer themselves to be overruled or deceived by their treasonable Councell: I erre not, and therefore I hope the World will cleer me, that I doe not abuse or so much as once name or mention the Presbyterians or their Proselytes. It is the Judgement of Cardan Seg. 5. Aph. 56.The begining of ♎ ill. Initium Arietis per se bonum est; turbulentum autem & malum librae initium. This Lunar Eclips is in the beginning of the signe Libra, which Cardan affirmes to be turbulent and evill; and in regard part of its greatest obscuration fals to be neer or fully in the seventh House, without doubt its the forerunner of many tumults, desperate designes, which will not terminate but in blood and ruine of those who first contrived and afterwards shall dare to execute them, or put them into Act.

This Eclips is in the middle of that Asterisme which we appropriate to the Virgin, over which Mercury rules, and it is humane, therefore the Events doe belong unto men. Asterismorum natura expenditur cum ex signatura; Orig. 461.

The nature of the Asterisme wherein the Eclips shall happen, as also its signature must be inquired after; now sith the signe viz: Libra, is humane, and the Asterisme also,
it hath much relation unto Mankinde and actions to be performed by Man, as Justice and upright Judgement,Complaint for Iustice. the want whereof this Eclips doth demonstrate, or its due and full execution. Supersunt alia etiam, proximè quidem ab ipsis hominibus oriunda; ut simultates, inimicitiae, bellorum turbines, quorum parens est Injustitia, dum quisque meum illud ac tuum ita tuetur, ut suae cupiditati nullum constituat modum; imo dum cuique quod suum est, reddere pollicentur, eripiunt meum ac tuum, communia faciunt cuncta, & bonis perpetuo inhiant alienis. Gemma lib. 1. 171.

There remaine many things besides, which prove as Engines to stir up men unto wickednesse, viz. dissimulations, emnities, which are the very whirlewinds or stirrers up of Warrs, whose Parent or first occasioner was Injustice, whil'st every one doth so defend that which is called Mine as if it were Thine; yet so as he who pretends to do this gives no restraint to his own covetous desires; nay whilst he or they do promise to give unto every one what is his, they violently take away both Mine and Thine, or my Right and thy Right; they make all things common, and still are hanging after other mens estates. Such like things it seems the generality of people in Germany, the Low Countries, France and England will speake of, and complaine of: I hope God will be mercifull unto the English Common-wealth, and suffer no such cause to remaine amongst us to give so generall a distaste, &c. Seeing this Eclips doth happen so neer the Spring, at what time men are preparing the Earth to receive Seeds;The Spring conceived to be moderate. De satione & rebus ex terra primùm prodeuntibus, de arborum fructiferarum pullulatione seu germinibus habet significationem, item vitis, ficuum aliorum{que} fructum spe; as Origanus will have it, and reason it selfe, 1461. Viz. the signification of this Eclips will have much to doe in such things or Seeds as Men sow neere this time, or put into the Earth, or on such Plants and Trees which doe now put forth themselves either in sprouting or budding, and these effects, viz. either to have unkindely windes or blasts, we must expect, in regard it fals in the very entrance of that season we in England vulgarly
call the Spring; though for my part I rather conceive the Spring more properly first begins at what time the Sunne enters Capricorne, When the Sp • ing properly begins. for that then the Sap of Trees and other Plants does first begin to dilate and ascend upward; the Sun then first beginning to incline from his furthest South Declination towards the North. We are also to consider that this signe Libra is equinoctiall, and therefore hath signification De sacris & religionis cultu potissimum, Orig. 461. Here will be much time consumed (perhaps lost) in discussing things holy,Time spent to no purpose about Ceremonies. or of Divine worship, or points of Faith, or Fundamentals in Religion.

It is very true, and we doe judge Religion will be much spoken of, much talked of, many disputes appearing to be about it, during the continuance of the effects of this eclips; for I well remember upon that memorable Eclips in or about the tenth of January 1639, the Scottish Nation raised an Army and made for their pretence of warre, onely an obtrusion upon their Nation of a semipopish Booke or Common prayer Book; The Scots first angry at the Common Prayer Booke. but the sad consequences which after that happened ended not so soon as it began, but in a most wofull distemper of both England and Scotland in much bloodshed and most fierce warrs: both nations haveing sensibly now been made understand of how dangerous a consequent it is to embroyle our selves into a warre upon the prateing and pretending Glosses of those we call Ministers who never care for the welfare of any other sort of People but of their own Hierarchy, Many Ministers respect themselves onely. that so they might Lord it and domineer like petty Tyrants over the Commonalty and Gentry. But if in this Eclips we consider either the strength of Jupiter or his position, we finde him wholly out of all Dignity either essentiall or accidentall. A Jove Praelatura, we have Jupiter to signifie Prelacy and Ecclesiasticall affaires. [Baranzanus; sub Jove principes, Ecclesiastici, politici, Sacerdotes. 224. Under Jupiter we signifie Princes, Cardinals, all Ecclesiasticall Potentates, Policy; and Sacerdotes, because it ever did, shall passe for Priests.] This Eclips findes them in much sorrow and anguish of minde (the influence of this Eclips crosses their Designes)
they now fearing the downfall of their Tythes,People unwilling to pay Tythes. and a generall tergiversation of the people against them in many places; the People who begin to see without Spectacles, generally declining their spurious and seditious Doctrines against Parlament and State, whether derived from John Calvin or the babling of a silly Scottish Presbytery. Ministry threatned all over Europe.

Farre be it from me to say that this judgement against Divines, shall be onely particular to England and Scotland; no assuredly; in many places of Germany, France, Italy and other Nations there will arise much trouble and affliction unto the whol Hierarchy of them, whether Papist or Protestant: this will generally fall upon them everywhere wheresoever they reside.

I rather write this with sorrow of heart then any joy or delight to see the downfal of so many men, who, had they improved their talents in Learning and divinity conscientiously for education of those flocks God had commited unto them,The Authors wel-wishes unto the godly Divines. might have expected an other manner of reward from heaven, and a more benigne acceptance of their labours from men: The great God of Heaven protect the pious and godly Divines of our Nation, for some we have: and let them never want incouragement or a most bountifull allowance from this Common wealth; but for the meer Prater or State enemy, let it be with him as he doth merit. The ruine or impoverishing of many of them is at hand; for Eclipsis in octava vel septima domo decrescentia & occidentia manif • stat, fini propinqua, quae jam inclinant ad mutationem, ut sunt senectus, vita functi, consuetudines Leges & institutorum in politiis mutationes. Origanus, 461: &c. An Eclips in the west angle or seven • h house, shews things declining and decreasing; viz. such things whereof the Eclips was a significator, and that they are neare unto an end, and that things incline unto a Change. Age is here concerned, and so the death of many aged men to follow; Customes and Lawes follow next in order to be altered or some changes to be made in them; Alterations also in things and matters Politicall, as Leagues, Civill institutions, &c. The Eclips having signification
of things Religious, portends what I have delivered, &c.

Who enemies to this Nation.This Eclips ending in the seventh house will manifest unto the English Nation somewhat De apertis inimicis, what Nation will be their friends, who will openly shew themselves professed enemies. Libra hath dominion over much of Germany, and signifies some clandestine Designe in hatching against our State by some of those petty German Princes, as also so some such like things either in Flanders, Antwerpe or thereabouts; Certainly, there is some eminent treason in or near those parts in agitation in or near the time of this Eclips or du • ing its influence to break forth; & if you would know about what or for whom; the Deflux of the Moon after her Eclips to the Quadrate of Jupiter tels you, its for the restating, or for assisting a King; and who this King can be but the King of Scots I know not;Plots in Holland against England. sith his significator, Jupiter, who is Lord of the tenth, is cadent in the twelfth, and peregrin, also approaching unto the opposition of Saturn, as poor as Job. But such is the fate of Princes, against whom the Divine hand of Providence frowns.

And this my conjecture I also conceive to be sufficiently evinced from the malevolent quadrate of Saturn unto Mars lately happened; as if either some injury had been lately done unto some of our Nation, or is neer doing, either by some of the Dutch or Scotch Nation,Great doubt of the Engl sh and Dutch agreeing. and further intimating no perfect agreement or conclusion with those people, some misfortune or misunderstanding making the breaches either wider really, or else publikely seeming so: Mischief I see is threatned and intended unto us in generall from the Hollander and Scot, quoad capaces, so far as God shall make them capable or able to mischieve us; Hollander an enemy to England. f • r seeing at the very end of the Eclipse the Moon her degree in Libra doth descend, and the ☉ then first riseth above the Horizon; I very much fear a War, or some Warlike attempts either by Sea or Land doe follow: The Lord God of Heaven turn it unto Consultations onely, and preparations, or Warlike Councels. Let no mans heart fail him; for so far as God doth manifest himself
in this naturall way of judicature, by his creatures the Stars, we English have no need to fear the Dutch: I wish from my soul a peace with them; but if God have ordained our Nation to be a scourge unto the Dutch, for their pride and injuries offered us this many yeers, I shall rejoyce that the justice of God is executed, but sorely lament either the blood or losse of Substance any Christian shall sustain in this quarrell. If possible, God divert his judgements from both Scot and Dutch.

I am not easily inclined to have any evill opinion of that Nation, with whom we have been so familiar, unto whom we have communicated so many helps, both in men and money, as have wholly made them Libertines, and weakned our selves; but assuredly the vengeance of Almighty God is ready to be poured forth upon the Dutch for their too too much unthankfulnesse. Yet forasmuch as both the Moon and Mercury are in aery Signs, and in a trine aspect, we may well hope that the Merchant as well as others of both N • tions, endeavour a right understanding betwixt us: However, I hope it will not displease the Presbytery, if I say our State are promised very fairly to be Victors either against the Dutch, French, Swede or Dane, or any other People of Germany, from whom we may have cause to expect an Hostility, or action of War, either by Sea or Land: Y • t assuredly those actions which will be agitated either by Embassadours or Agents, or by Officers of War of any Nation, will be acted with a high and mighty hand, with all the might and power its possible they can prepare.

We constitute Venus Ruler of the place eclipsed, Ireland like to be happy ere long. and she in Taurus, applying to a trine of Jupiter: Were not the murders of our English crying unto God for vengeance; th •
I • ish might begin to be happy; but thrice happy will all those English be, who shall adventure their estates and persons into Ireland, this Eclipse promising the English all happinesse under so wise, so prudent and vigilant a Lord D • puty, and such provident Commissioners.

But sith this is the first Eclipse, and is Lunar, and so presently
succeding the ingresse of Sol into Aries, we shall take liberty to intermix part of our judgement with what we shall be enabled to deliver upon the grand Eclipse of the Sunne.

The duration of this Lunar Eclipse will be three hours and a half, or somewhat more, and therefore the eff • cts will continue three moneths and about eighteen dayes, beginning the latter end of December next, and ending in April following: But although the effects shall most operate then, yet doubtlesse long before; nay, even presently after its appearance, matters will be making ready and preparing in the fancies and conceits of men. But I forbear further to treat of this, and hasten to the eminent Solar Eclipse.

div.head:
Of the famous ECLIPS of the SUN, 1652. Munday, 29th March, 9. 56. A. M.
astrological chart
The Sun Eclipsed. ☽ 29: Mar: 1652. 9:56 AM LONDINUM Angliae:
stylized depiction of an eclipse
div.p: NIhil sine Deo & Sole. Nothing is perfect in this World without God and the Sun; thus said Clemens Alexandrinus: Omnibus infusus est, omnibus intimus; per hunc ardent in coelo tot syderum faces, per hunc stant elementa, venti spirant, plantae vigent, sentiunt animantes; & quod mireris, eodem temporis momento hic diem, hic noctem inducit; inde serenat, inde coruscat in fulgura, subit in aquas, riget in grandinem, sexcentarum artium unus & semper artifex, caeruleo nubes pingit, • uro vestit montium Culmina, &c.

p.hi: Q • ae in Coelo aut in terris fiunt, hunc orientem omnes natura duce animantes spectant, omnium si quidem proprium est Solis Luce afflatuque laetari.

div.p: The Sun is infused in all things, intimate in all things, by him so many glorious Lamps of Heaven do shine, by him the Elements stand, the Winds blow, the Plants florish, living Creatures have sense; and what is wonderfull, at the same moment of time he produces the Day here and the Night there. Here it is faire Weather, by and by Thunder, Stormes and Lightning: He passeth into Waters, then into Hayle; being ever one and the same Artifect of six hundred Arts; he paints the Clouds with Azure colour, cloathes the tops of Mountains with Gold.

Whatever Creatures are either in the Heavens or Earth, all of them doe love the Sunne arising, Nature being guide; it is the property of all living Creatures to rejoyce with the Light and refreshment of the Sunne.

q.l: O Sol qui mediis graderis pulcherrimus Astris,

div.p: Shall we then say, or be so innocent of the heavenly Ordinances, as to deny this great Luminary any influence upon humane and mundane affairs; Causinus, lib. 47. or to be so stupid, as to think that when this Light is obscured from us, that there is nothing thereby signified unto mortal men? sint in signa & tempora, God created the two Lights, or Sun and Moon, for signs and seasons.

Quis dubitat Iridem naturaliter fieri, & tamen huic serenitatis rediturae praesagia Deus annexuit; sic & Eclipsis haud dubie turbato ex defectu Luminarium mundo, morbis, funeribus, casibusque sinistris comitatri solet, quod tam saepe compertum experimentis. Who doubts that the Rain bow is naturall? and yet God hath appointed it the presage or fore-runner of fair weather to be at hand: so an Eclipse, without question, the world being troubled by the defect of the Luminaries (viz. Sun or Moon) is ever attended, as we know by experience, with diseases, sad accidents, as concomicants of it.

Ficinus, lib. Epist. 6. pag. 120. Plotinus the Platonist was wont to say, eff • ctus infra Lunam penè omnes à Coelo significari: all events below the Moon were in a manner fully signified or discovered by the Heavens.

And although Avicen was no gr • at friend to Astrology, yet he affirmed, Coelum est animal obediens Deo, viz. Heaven is a creature obedient to God. And a little after, idcirco ouando de Coelestium corporum virtute loquuntur Astrologi, rarissimè quidem aium Coelestia hoc aut illud facere; frequentissimè vero asserunt, tale aliquid aut tale significari: Wherefore when Astrologers doe speak of the vertue a • d influence of the Stars, or Heavenly bodies, they tarely (I say never) affirm, the Celestiall bodies act or doe such a thing; but very frequently they maintain, they signifie such or such a thing.

And Ficinus that excellent learned Priest, in his lib. 6. Epist. fol. 820. saith, Multa per Coelum significantur, quae non fiunt in Coelo: Many accidents are signified or foreseen by the Stars, which are not done in Heaven. And again, Multa per Coelestia corpora tanquam per signa non per causas praedicuntur: Many things are foretold by means of the Heavenly bodies, as it were by signs, not by causes.

The opinion of this man I esteem more then of a thousand of our own Priests, who bl • me Astrology because it's above their capacity: I pitty their errour, because grounded rather upon malice and ignorance, then a sound enquiry. Quid de Luminum deliquiis? (saith Pucer pag. 382. de Astrologia) an horum, Planetarumque his aut assistentium, aut radiis accumbentium, effectiones inficiabimur, & significata, quorum tristi deformique aspectu omni tempore hominum animi conterriti expaverunt, • repidaruntque, occulto scilicet sensu naturae praesagientes secutura damna?

What shall I say, or why shall I trifle out my time, saith the learned Peucer, against such as deny the influence of the Heavenly bodies? What shall we say concerning the Eclipses of the Sun and Moon? Are we our selves, or any rationall Men ignorant, that the Eclipses of the Sunne and Moone, and the Radiations and Aspects of the other Planets concomitant and assistant with those Eclipses, their good or bad Aspects each unto other? Doe we not know, saith he, their Significations in all Ages have been ominous, and caused Mens minds to be terrified by a secret and occult sence of the miseries and calamityes those Eclipses did presage to be neare at hand or to follow presently after those Eclipses?

Neque innoxie unquam vel suam abscondit faciem Sol, Lunae contectam interventu; nec opus est veterum annotata ut citemus; usurpemus ea exempla, quorum recens in hominum animis viget memoria: The Sun at no time is in vain eclipsed, or hides his face by interposition of the Moon, without some prejudice at hand. We need not herein have recourse to what the Ancients have delivered, but let us use the examples of our own Age which are fresh in memory.

p.hi: Quantos incendit aestus, quam diu flagrantes Solis sub Ariete anno Quadragesimo?
Quos motus in orbe terrarum commovit, cum haec Solis, tum altero anno post Lunae Eclipsis?

Quantas lites, quam superba dissidia, & occulta odia insidiasque, quam violenta concilia severint struxerintque, quae bella induxerint, quae pericula nocumentaque frumento fructibusque crearint, deliquia anni quadragesimi quarti; cum Luna tota atra caligine ter faedum in modum deformaretur?

div.p: Sol plus deunce sui orbis obfuscaretur, adeo ut in quibusdam locis interdiu stellae illuxerint, ac conspectae sint eo ipso et sequentibus annis ex eventu didicimus &c. Peucer. 382.

How many hot Summers, how great was the heat, how scortht were the Fields upon an Eclips in Aries? What tumults and seditions all over the world, did the effects of this Eclips stirre up, when together with one of the Moon the next yeare they were in full force? How great Quarrels, how proud and domineering Insults, Deceipts, Hatreds, what furious Consultations did these sow the seeds of? what horrid Wars did they produce? what harmes unto Corn and unto the Fruits of the Earth did they Create? I mean those Eclipses about the yeare 1544, when as the whole body of the Moon with a fearfull blacknesse was thrice obscured from the sight of mortall man; the sun in those yeares was more then eleven Digits Eclipsed; insomuch that in many places in the day time Stars did shine, and were sensibly apparant. From this and other Eclipses in the following yeares, we have learned by the event of those, what hereafter shall be expected.

But let us come to the intended subject, viz. an Eclips of the Sun, and is the greatest this Age hath beheld, from whence you may exp • ct accidents or effects to follow sutable to the greatnesse; for it was rightly observed by Ludovicus De Rigij. Prudenter solem considera; nam judicia solis non sunt oblivioni tradenda: in every greater, meaner or lesser Conjunction of the superiors, in every Eclips, in every Radix of any eminent Accident, consider prudently the Sun and his
affection, for in no wise maist thou forget his signification; nor by the leave of the Creator of mankind, will we in our discourse neglect what we may from naturall causes extract from this memorable eclips of the Sun in our ensuing Astrologicall judgement.

Divine providence hath ordered this Eclips to be celebrated in a fiery Equinocti • ll signe.Equinoctiall Signes, what they signifie. Signa aequinoctialia sunt Ascendentia regnorum Mundi, per ea quae imperia eorum principia habuerunt, & fundamenta earum urbium civitatesque caeterae quae in principio suarum aedificationum ex istis habente in ascendente; omnes imperio proprio conantur dominari regereque. Equinoctiall signes (viz. Aries and Libra) are the ascendants of Kingdomes or Dominions of this world, being that or those signs & the Lords thereof were strong and well fortified when such an Empire or Kingdome first obtained i' • s soverainty or greatnesse, or they were the ascendants at what time such or such a City first laid the foundation of its greatnesse, or when that City had its first foundation or building erected; for every Kingdome & City naturally desires & endevors to be regulated, and to order i'ts or their aff • ires, according as the position of Heaven was at i'ts first structure or first arising unto greatnesse: The English nation have Aries the Ascendant of England;
Aries the Ascendant of England. therefore let us observe that as often as either any memorable Eclips doth therein happen, or any eminent Conjunction of the superior Planets, and we shall find cause to wonder at the wise ordering of the Almighty, who thereby acquaints us what he intends towards us near upon those times, either for our good or evill; and this assuredly and grounded upon the experience of at least twenty generations of men.

Conjunctio Luminarium in Ariete facit alterationes & mort • s: Carda. Seg. 4. 89. The Conjunction of the two Luminaries in Aries, o • casions strange Alienations of freindship and Death. viz. breach of Leagues, Amities and friendships; from thence Warre and controversy, after which follows quarrels, and then Death and Destruction; many times a • s • Famine and scarcity of provisions; for although both the Oppositions
and Quadratures either of the Luminaries or of the Grand Planets are in themselves obnoxious,A Conjunction most forcible. yet Seg. 4. Aphor. 104. Conjunctio plurimum validior est oppositione &c. the Conjunction of the Luminares or Planets for the most is more forcible then either Opposition or Quadrate; from hence let us expect the more manifest and grander effects, where ever Providence shall designe them to fall; for in a conjunction there is union of Beames: Nor are men or Cattle onely concerned in this our great Eclips; without doubt whole Kingdomes, Nations, People, Cities and Common-wealths.

Eclipses Luminarium super Civitates, Provincias & Regna, magis quam super privatae conditionis homines, Many Cities • nd Common-wealths concerned. aut etiam super Reges; respiciunt enim multitudinem, Seg. 5. Apho. 45.

The Eclipses of the Luminaries have signification, or operate by their influence upon Cities, Provinces and Kingdomes more forcibly then on Men of private condition or upon Kings; for their effects generally have relation to the Multitudes or Many People. Whereupon Dasipodius Apho. 58. did deliver thus much, Ex Eclipsibus magni effectus proveniunt, viz. from the influence of Eclipses great and wonderfull effects doe succeed. Nor can we expect lesse from this we now treat of, then great Changes amongst great Kingdoms, Cities, Common-wealths and Families. Magnorum principum Sol est Significator. Seg. 4. Apho. 107. The Sunne is Significator of great Princes, Emperors, Men of great Authority. The Moone of Women in generall, and more particularly of Queenes, great Ladies, Empresses, in our present Eclipse,Great changes upon Eclipses▪ in the fiery Trigon. because it is a Regall house and signe. And sith we have mentioned Aries to be a Regall signe, as indeed it is, and the first of the Zodiack; Leo the second Regall signe, and Sagittarius the third; we shall acquaint Posterity, that the greatest and most materiall Changes-and alterations of this World, have alwayes succeeded either a great Conjunction of the Superiors, or some wonderfull and great Eclips in the Fiery Trigon, whereof these Conjunctions have been the Prodromi.

Elementi ignei praedominium ad reges, civitatumque praefectos pertinet; ignis enim agendi efficacia maxime valet; erumpit aestu horrendo ignis omnia dissipans atque consumens. The predominion of the Element of fire, appertaines to the signification of Kings, Governors of Cities:Eclipses in the Mid-Heaven worke violently. for the vigor and efficacy of fire is very fierce, it violently rusheth forth with an horrible noyse and heat, dissipating, dispersing and consuming every thing which opposeth it. Now for as much as the Sunne, who is by nature hot, becomes Eclipsed in a Signe Regall, hot and dry, and in the most eminent and conspicuous House of Heaven, I say, the effects depending on heat, shall impetuously and furiously operate, according to Cardanus in the 7. Seg. Apho. 76. Maximus vigor in istis Eclipsibus quae contingent in Coeli corde. viz. those Eclipses doe most terribly manifest their effects, or doe most vigorously operate, which fall to be in the Heart of Heaven, viz. in the Midheaven. With whom concurreth Proclus in lib. 2. pag. 65. Vehementiores effectus sunt in sublimi & medio Coeli, magnam Sphaerae partem occupantes. The effects of Eclipses falling in the Midheaven are more vehement, as occupying a great part of the Sphear.

Miros effectus producit Eclipsis magna in signo igneo & regio; wonderfull are those effects of an Eclips which will follow when it is in a fiery and regall Signe, as this of which we now discourse of is; and as this Eclips hath its first obscuration as it were in the tenth house, and its greatest obscurity and end neare the very heart or Center of that house, which is (validior omnibus coeli domibus) so questionlesse those people who are intended to be made most sensible of this Eclipses influence, are in part Kings, Emperors, Princes, Dukes, Magistrates of the highest rank and quality in every N • tion of Europe; and these so great Alterations in this Macrocosme shall be so glorious, so conspicuous and apparent, that there is no Nation or people of Europe, Asia or Affrica, but they shall stand amazed and wonder at the eminency of them; Solis enim opera manifestissima sunt, as Dasipodius observes, the glorious works of the Sun, or those effects signified by his influence in a great Eclips are the most evident and manifest
and operate the most upon mankind. And assuredly we may expect no lesse then miraculous Accidents to ensue after this Eclips,Great matters from this Eclips. it being so great, and the Digits Eclipsed so many; Maximae eclipses & maximè sperantur; for the greatest Eclipses produce the greatest effects, and most lively operate accordingly on that matter they are the forerunners of.

Now forasmuch as this Eclips will be in the Sign of Aries, and as we said before, that Sign is Aequinoctiall, Dasipodius Apho. 79. saith, Signa Aequinoctialia sentiuntur dominium habere super status legum, This Eclips • oncerns Pres
• itery. ut sunt sacrae ceremoniae, haereses, sacerdotia, Pontificatus: An Eclips in an Aequinoctiall Sign, hath dominion, or shall signifie, or shall operate on such matters as concern the state and condition of Lawes, Ceremonies, Heresies, or strange opinions, Priesthoods, Pōpery, or things concerning the Papacy or Prelacy; I may very well adde Presbytery, &c.

How far the influence of this Eclipse shall operate upon the common Lawes of our Nation, I cannot very well tell; but sure I am, not to its overthrow, but regulating; or how far it shall exasperate mens spirits against the Clergy of our own and other Nations, or how far it shall torment the poor Husband-man, to depart with the tenth part of his labour unto his insufficient or factious Minister, or prating Priest,The Common Law wil stand but Presbytery down. I am not able cleerly to determine; great afflictions in one way or other this Eclips doth generally manifest to happen unto all those of the long Robe, viz Lawyers, Civilians, Clergy-men, and unto those we falsly for the most part call Divines, when God knows many of them have as little knowledge of Divinity, as my self of Presbyter John, and as little affection for the Parlament, as my self zeal for Antichrist. But forasmuch as Jupiter and Saturn were in reception, though by opposition, I judge it will goe hard with the Law it self, but not to its extirpation, as some senslesse people would have it; no, it will stand, viz. the Law, I mean the common Law of England, untill and after that generall Shires are made Provinciall in this Nation;
