nay, it will then flourish: but in the interim, much strugling and much heart-burning there will be against it, to no purpose, as to extirpation: for the Law, I mean the Common Law it selfe in some more purity,The Common Law most excellent. being to continue so long as men shall inhabit that portion of ground we vulgarly call ENGLAND: it is grounded upon pure reason, and of it self is the most equall, and most just Law that ever did appear in any N • tion, giving every man his right, and tryall by his equals; herein we allow no abuse.

Nor are the English onely concerned in that or those great Catastrophes which will appear after this so famous Eclips; for as it will be visible more or lesse in all or the most place • of Europe; so according unto Origanus, Institu. Page 454. Quando Eclipses sunt generales, non modo orbes multas, sed & Regiones integras sub quadrangulo imprimis signi, in quo Eclipsis fit, constitutas; imo & homines habentes cognationem in genesi sua cum themate Eclipsis, afficiunt: When Eclipses are generall (as this almost is) they doe not onely afflict very many Cities, but whole Countries subject to the Quadrangle of that Sign in which the Eclips is: nay, they afflict men also, when the Eclipses have affinity or relation in their Nativity with the T ••• am of the Eclipse: of which hereafter.

Nam etsi naturaliter motu, conjunctione vel oppositione nimirum Luminarium prope Nodos sive caudam & caput Draconis fiant: tamen defectus ille Luminis non sine effectu est, cum natura nil faciat frustra; & compertum habeamus, tumultus, seditiones, pestes, famem, grandines, inundationes, calamitatem▪ Calamities following Eclipses. denique praesertim Solarem portendisse. S • tlerus, pag. 74.

Although naturally by motion in a new or full Moon, neer unto the two Nodes (or more properly to the head and tail of the Dragon) they become eclipsed; yet is not that defect or want of light without effect, sith N • ture doth nothing in vain; and we daily know by expe • ience, that Tumults, Seditions, Plagues, Famine, storms of Hail, Inundations, Calamities in severall kinds, are ever concomitant, or doe follow an Eclips of the Sun, the more great by how much the Eclips is great.

Let us now see in what Asterism or Constellation of the twelve SignsOf the 12. Signes. this so prodigious an Eclips shall appear; for we are as well to consider the Asterism as the Sign, and the form of that Sign wherein the Eclips is; significantia Eclipsis decreta sunt ejus, quae proprius cardines; considera etiam naturam stellarum simul consistentium, tum erraticarum, tum fixarum, ac etiam simulacra coorientia, & secundum haec pronuntia: Ptol. Apho. 96. Those Eclipses which are apparent,Constellations to be observed. and neer unto the Angles of the Figure, doe most apparently manifest their effects; the neerer unto the Angles, the more vigorously they operate: consider also the nature of the fixed Stars and Planets neer unto the place eclipsed, and the image and form of that Constellation which arises with the Sign wherein the Eclips is.

With Ptolomey doth agree an unknown Author, in his 254. Aphorism, Ne obliviscaris imaginum stellarum fixarum, in quibus accident Eclipses vel conjunctiones magnae: quia secundum has accidunt notabiles effectus, viz. Be not unmindfull of the images of the fixed Stars, wherein the Eclipses or great Conjunctions doe happen; because according unto these, notable effects doe happen: together with these, consider what fixed Stars doe either culminate or arise at time of the Eclips its greatest obscuration. This Eclips then falling out in the 19. of Aries, and some few minutes, is in the last part of that Asterism we attribute to Pisces, of which Jupiter is Lord; and these parts of this Asterism formerly as well as now, aestuabant, aerem incrassando & obtenebrando, viz. did heat very much, and also cause a thick and cloudy ayre; and this part being northerly is windy: From whence will arise this judgement, That as Jupiter is Lord of the Asterism,The Asterism. here will be great mutation in the Magigistracy of Nations, in the change and alteration of Governours, in the Lawes, Customes and constitutions of People, Cities and Countries, in setling the Ministry in those Countries which are professours of the Protestant faith, much regulation & curbing a seditious, disorderly & ambitious Clergie; nor are the Protestants of Europe more concerned
then the Popish party; for doubtlesse the Religious orders of houses amongst themselves, will be at great variance and discord amongst themselves, about each others rights, priviledges and precedencies: so also will there be great controversie amongst the Superiours of each Order; as also amongst the Cardinals, Bishops, Arch-Bishops, Abbots, and Priors, and such like; amongst and amidst their most serious debates, and in their most private Conclaves.

There doth arise with the degree ascending a most notable fixed star of the first magnitude, seated in the right shoulder of Orion, of the nature of Mars and Mercury; and these are in the last part of the Asterism of Gemini, whose governour is Mercury; from hence will arise dangerous Consultations, clandestine Designs, sudden and violent Councels, pernicious and destructive; this Constellation stirring up the minds and resolutions of men, both Souldiers, Lawyers and vulgar men,Rash Councels. to prosecute their Designs with fury and madnesse rather then discretion; for that part of this Asterism abounding with many fixed starsFixed Stars. of the nature of Saturn, Mars and Mercury, elevates the minds of men, yet subtilly to goe on with their resolutions, untill perfected.

The northern part of this Asterism in which our Ascendant is (movet ventos & terras concutit) viz. stirs up strong winds in the ayre, and strange fantasies in the brains of men; it also shakes the earth, viz. the Plants and budding young Trees with storms, hail and tempests; and in man, it amazes his councels, and puts his wits unto a stand.

Eclipsis in signo mobili, rem convertibilem vel ad bonum vel ad malum denuntiat. Sea contentions about Fishing. Hermes Apho. 80. An Eclips in a movable Sign, shews the matters or things thereby signified to be convertible either to good or evill: And in regard the Eclips it self is in the Asterism of the Fishes, it may denote much contention upon Water, or the Seas, about the rights of Fishing, either of our own Nation, the Hollander, or some other Northern People: as also in regard Jupiter hath significations of Lawes, and Rights and Priviledges Politicall, there may be doubted much controversie to arise about
the Priviledges of our Nation, and their rights to the dominion of those Seas our carefull Ancestors have left us; for as the degrees arising in our Horizon are almost in a partill quadrate unto the degree eclipsed, and to both the Luminaries, being neer unto Saturn in an Humain Asterime, having the shape of two yong Twins or yong Men; it may from hence be probably deduced, that some Men of two severall Nations or Countries,Caution to the Engl sh. or Men pretending one thing to our State, and ayming at another, may joyne in one, or in a League, to bereave the English of their Sea-rights, by deceit, fraud, by Treaties, if possible, else in plain termes, by Warre and severall Fleets at Sea.

For it is excellently well observed by Rigel Aph. 55. Cancer the sign ascending, Significator est super aquas multū mobiles, Pisces quoque super immobiles, scilicet lacunas & puteos. The signe Cancer hath signification of such waters as ebb & flow; the sign Pisces of such as move not, viz. either Ponds, Havens or still waters; it gives us English especially warning to beware as well of our decayed Havens, that they be looked unto, as also of our Ships, for feare of surprizals in Harbors; as also to our Navy which floates on the Seas, that either in a calme when not suspected, we be not indangered by fire or other casualties; for we may feare deceipt and treachery in the Hollander and others in stopping up our Harbours or Havens, and must prudently provide also for and against theirs and other Fleets at Sea; Hollander is deceitfull. for Saturne in Cancer, Naufragia permulta • , Saturne in Cancer signifies many Shipwracks at Sea, many Fleets preparing in severall parts of the World; much theevery and Pyracy, great decay of Shipping, and much injury to Sea-Townes and their Harbours and Havens; for if we consider the Houses of Heaven whereof he hath Dominion, we shall finde him Lord of the ninth in part, and wholly of the eight and seventh; as if in long journeys and Sea Voyages, Stormes, Sea-fights and Shipwracks, many Ships would come to Destruction. Oportet maximum impedimentum esse rerum quae sunt in potestate signi in quo fuerit planeta cadens aut in malo esse solis. There will be a great impediment of
such things and in such things, as have relation to the Sign in which a Plamet is posited, either being cadent or in evill aspect of the Sunne.Sea fights danger to Harbours. Now if the Signe Cancer signifie the Sea, as we all know it doth, Saturn possessing the Sign, and both in his detriment and in quadrate of the Sun; from hence we may expect such mischiefs at Sea as predicted, and such impediments or blocking up of Harbours, or Sea-fights, &c.

It addes unto the calamities above specified, that Saturn is in a feminine Sign, according to that 83. Aphorism of Rigel, Majus infartunium Saturni est cum fuerit in Signis faemininis, viz. Saturn is most obnoxious when he is in feminine Signs; but as he is posited now in an Angle, efficacius producit effectus, he works more vigorously and to greater purpose: And as we have said, he will operate on the Sea, and in Sea-affairs, so also in regard he is Planetarum altissimus, & tardissimus rari simè alicui Planetae applicanti, propter hoc significat magnos principes & stabiles Monarchas; being Saturn is the highest of the Planets, and in motion most slow,Great Turke is threatned, Kings and Emperors. seldome applying unto any Planet, unlesse he be Retrograde, therefore he doth signifie great Emperours, great Kings, such Monarchs and Monarchies as have firmly stood and continued many Ages, or a long time; hereby let the grand Seignieur or great Turk beware of Tumults and Seditions in his so vast Territories, but especially in Constantinople, and in those his Provinces which lye in Greece: and so also the Emperour of Germany, and many parts of Austria, Hungaria▪ and Bulgaria; nor is the King of Spain exempted, whose Dominions and Territories exceed the Emperours: Aries being the Ascendant of some parts of France, threatens that Nation with War and Bloodshed, with forraign Invasion; Capricorn being under the same Quadrangle of the Sign of the Eclips,Austria, Hungaria, Germany West Indies. threatens Brazile and the West Indias all over.

Nor is there any probable argument to be drawn from hence that the Dutch shall recover Brazile, &c. it doth rather import th • ir further l • sses in the West Indias, both of Men, Ships and Commodities; nor are they ordained by
Providence to be the Moderators of Europe, The Holander must not m •
derate Europe. or its affairs.

This is the forerunner of more poverty and beggery in Scotland, and of Tumults and Seditions in other Countries which lye in more Northerly latitude then 53. and of some preparation of Ships and Shipping, Men, Arms and Ammunition, for some Invasion against our Commonwealth: How firmly the Pole and Muskovite Pole and Muscovite. are linked in friendship, I know not, they are feverely threatned from the influence of this great Eclips; so also is the Queen of Sweden threatened to have great division in her Court and Countryes, and some sad misfortune to her Armies or Subjects▪ from such as she very little dreams of.

Nor can I find the Danish King in any security, assuredly some Navall preparation he intends,Denmarke. and much scuffling there will be neer the Sound, or in those Seas whereof he claims a Soveraignty.
And although I find the Pyrates of Algier will be active in their Pyracies,Pyrates Algier. yet are they signified to have more losse then gain by means of their Sea-thieving.

Zealand and Holland Zealand, Holland. may expect further irruption of their Sea-banks, and abundance of losse and damage in their Maritine affairs, infinite losses by Shipwracks, Storms, Pyracies, and without the mercy of God, strange murmuring • , if no uproar or Tumults of the Clown and Boors against both their Provinciall and State Governours; for if we beleeve Cardan in Seg. 7. and 122. Aph. Detrimenta rerum fiunt maximè locis quae sub sunt ascendenti, & qui in aspectu sunt constitutionum, & his qui eidem sub sunt Trigono: Those Countries which are subject unto the Sign ascending in an Eclipse, shall suffer exceeding many losses or detriments, as also those who are in aspect or subject unto the same Trigon: Woe unto thee Holland, Zealand, Scotland; Venice, Algier, Constantinople, &c. if this prove true. Nor is the States of Venice Venice. any way secured, but rather heavily threatned with much damage and detriment in their Sea-affairs; much poverty, if not the destruction of some one or more of their greatest Cities, and severall losses unto their Navy.

The Genoa Merchants, Amsterdam past its grea •
est glory. and the Amsterlodamians will assuredly smart in their adventures to the East India; that City hath past its greatest height, and will from hence d • cline, as having neither sence of Civility or compassion of those who are afflicted. The Duke of Savoy and his Teritories doe seeme unto me to be aimed at by some petty Princes of Italy, or there are a people in Consultation how to beget trouble unto him, Italy without doubt hath much to act in this Eclips its effects; wonderfull are the private Councels of the Roman Conclave, Italy and Savoy. England is concerned in their Consultations; the subjection of the English Parlament and Common-wealth are the subjects of many private Councells, some Grandees some Prince or forlorn Creatures offer subjection unto that See; Will an Agnus Dei, or a Crucifix, or a Popish Relique though inclosed in a silver Box and Kissed toties quoties restore a Scotish King to the Crown of England? But insurrections, warrs, seditions, one Prince in Armes against another may there be expected,The Pope in danger. the Pope being Pontifex maximus, seems to be eclipsed by some act or other, and in danger either of death, or some private misfortune, &c▪ for Apho. 26. of Ludovicus a Regiis it is said; Nec in hoc te esse immemorem volo, quod urbs Romana a Capricorno, & Religio Romanorum a Libra principium sumpserint, &c.

Nor would I have thee to be unmindfull, that the City of Rome had its first structure or Renovation from Capricorn, and its height to Religion from some eminent Eclips or Conjunction of the superiors in Libra; the meaning of which Aphorisme is no more then this, that the principall affaires of the City of Rome are subject unto the influence of the signe of Capricorn, it being under the first Quadrangle and that at what time the high Priests or Popes did first beget their supremacy over the most Nations of Europe, it was upon some great Conjunction or Eclips in Libra. The onely reason according to naturall causes, why there hath been so many mutations, Heresies and severall orders of Religious men and sects in that Hierarchy, because that both Capricorn and Libra are signes moveable: and produce actions as
moveable as the signs; for when as providence had ordered that some eminent Eclips • s,When changes did arise in the Roman Chu • ch. and great, mean, and lesser Conjunctions should be c • lebrated in signes contrary unto the former, then and in those times did many mutations arise in the Roman church and all over Europe contrary to those the Church of Rome had formerly received, generally for the worse viz. one error creeping forward in the neck of another, Rigel 32. Deteriorantur enim genera hominum per transmutationes illarum magnarum, cum succedentes inimicabilite • configurantur cum figuris praeteritarum, &c. the kinds and qualities of men and mankind are made more degenerate and bad, by transmutation of those great Conjunctions, when as those Conjunctions which succeed are contrary to those went before, &c.

Family of Tuthers how long it continued.And herein we shall need to proceed no further then 1603. the great Cojunction of Saturn and Jupiter then begining in the fiery Trigon gave a period to the family of Tutbers or Tedders descended of Brittish Race, which began under the watery Trigon, and as it were providentially determined with the Consummation of it, that family having swayed the English Monarchy about 117 yeares.

Stuarts family how long it raigned.The family of Stuarts entred also upon the govenment of this Nation 1603. somewhat before the Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter, which not long after followed, and they continued, I meane two Princes of the Stuarts family, about forty years in glory, but in 1642/3. upon the effects of the Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter in Pisces, a Conjunction, contrary to their Radix; we know that Families declination; nor is their hopes in Nature of its re-establishment or rising again, though there will not want both the industry of men, and assistances of the greatest Princes and States of Europe for re-setling that Family; greatest Sticklers in time will appear to be the most unthankfull of men, the Dutch.

Nay, this very Eclips doth designe out some such thing, viz. severall designs in agitation at present in forrainge parts against the Common wealth of England by the Agents
of the Scottish King, and I doe fear some secret plots are now acting in forraign parts, yea in England and Scotland, Designes in Germany to re-establish the Scottish King. with intention to make Ireland the seat of some further unlucky War; for Mars who doth dispose of this great Eclips in whose house it is; he, I say, is seated in Taurus the Ascendant of Ireland, but in the s • cond part of the Asterisme of Aries which he governs; from whence either war in Ireland or great famine is to be expected, with destruction of their Cattle, and little expectation of plentifull Harvests &c.

Seeing we have spoken somewhat of the Asterismes of the signs, it shall not be tedious unto the Reader if I also further expatiate my mind concerning the greatnes of the effects of this Eclips, I do beleeve I shall go very near to hit the mark aright in what I deliver now. Notabimus imagines Decanorum in quibus accident Eclipses nam secundum illos verificantur effectus: Anonimus 276. Apho.

Let us consider the Images of the Decanats in which the Eclipses are; for according unto them the effects of Eclipses are verified. Every signe hath three Decanates, the first ten degrees of every Sign make the first Decanate, the second ten degr. make the second decanate of that sign, the ten last degr. make the third Decanate. This great Eclips is in the last degree of the second Decanate of Aries, and it is the Face of the Sun; the first Decanate of Aries being governed by Mars, this second by the Sun, the third by Ʋenus. This second Decanate we find to be Nobilitatis, Altitudinis, Regni, & magni Dominij Imago, viz. The Image of Nobility, Greatnesse, Dominion, extraordinary Rule: the Ancients did thus represent the shape and form of it, under this ensuing Image.

p.note: This presents the English Commonwealth as it will be for 3 years or thereabout, viz. in great Majesty and glory.

figure.figDesc: man dressed in a long, fur-edged robe

div.p: And though I find and beleeve some Man or Men, some Commonwealth or State in Europe shall attain unto a very great Dominion or Power, and this by War, Policy, Stratagems, Designs, &c. for the twentieth degree of Aries wherein this Eclips falleth out to be, is represented by Johannes Angelus, in the form following.

figure.figDesc: man in armor riding a bull and leading a horse

p.note: This presents the State of England after a few yeares, viz. the soldier tilling the ground, his Armes laid a side, A peaceable time, yet the soldier ever prepared.

div.p: His Image, Homo coopertus capite galea, cum penna strucii Taurum equitans & a sinistris equum ducens. A Soldier have his head covered with an Helmet, riding a Bull, with the Pen or quill of an he Sparrow, and a spare Horse in his hand.Some will account him so. His Motto or the meaning of his thus riding, is expressed in these words; Homo malitiosus erit. This Man will be a malicious Man.

Yet I say, in regard that this Eclips doth happen in the last Degree of that Decanate, and that next Decanate is governed by Venus; I say, that the Dominion or soveraignty which is signified to be attained by some Man or State at first by deceit and cruelty, or will be attained by War and great labor and industry, fraud, deceit, blood and what not; yet afterwards it shall be ordered with sweetnes; by subtilty, mercy, affability, policy; and this you may observe in the Type following.

p.note: This seemes to promise a cess • tion of all Taxes and all things governed by Love.

p.hi: Tertia facies Arietis est Veneris, & est subtilitatis in operè, & mansuetudinis: ludorum, gaudiorum & limpidationum.

div.p: The third face or Decanat of the sign Aries is of Venus; and it represents Subtilty, mildenesse, Playes, Joy or rejoycings, Clearnes, &c. A new Soveraignty, or manner of Government, Dominion or Rule is expected to have its first appearance, or signification of greatnesse from the effects of this Eclips; and it shall continue in somwhat a rigid posture; but in much Majesty or austerity, untill almost 1663. at what time all sharpnesse and bitternesse will be laid aside, and matters ruled mildely.

True it is, that upon the effects of that Eclips in 1654. in Leo, very great matters in things Politique,The Eclips in 1654. will second the actions of these. as Leagues and Friendships may be expected; yet will those Actions rather second and continue what are now and shall be produced upon the eff • cts of this and these Eclipses on the stage of Mankinde, or first take root and being, then any way checke or countermand them. If we consider the positure of heaven upon the great Mutation of the two superiors in 1603. we shall now finde our Eclips to be the very degree of the then 4th. House, as if these great Mutations and Catastrophes in every Commonwealth did not by chance or haz • rd come to their perfections or greatnesse,Nature is regular. or to their disturbance and disq • ietnesse, but by a regular and orderly course of Nature, who acts nothing in vaine, one while exalting and making small Families Great, and againe depressing other Magnificent Families, even unto Poverty. I say that now the very degree of the then 4th. House is the degree of this Eclips, and placed in the best and most eminent house of Heaven. Old things are departed; New Men, new Lawes, new Magistrates, new Commonwealths; Monarchy generlly disl ked in every Kingdome, every King in Europe either disturbed with the seditions of his owne People,New Commonwealths since 1603. or infested by powerfull neighbour Princes, every Prince daily in feare of some incursion or other from his Neighbours. This Eclips ending in the tenth House. Perfecta quae jam in Acme sunt & vigent in honore, ut frumenta m •• si • us vicina, aetatem virilem, reges, Magistratus, templa & arces; Monarchy disturbed every where. viz. The eff • cts of this Eclips will have dominion on such things as are even perfect and stand or florish in their height of Majesty, and shine in honour or greatnesse, and are even as the ripened Fruit or Corne is neere to the Harvest ready to be gathered and to repose. Th • se eff • cts will be manifested on Men who are fully Men, or of middle age, viz. from thirty unto fifty; upon Kings, Magistrates;Quality of Men passive in this Eclips on Churches, Towers, Castles, &c. Origanus 462.

Res quae a syderibus ex generalibus constitutionibus eveniunt, non sunt unae sed plures, & hae variae atque multiplices. D • sip • dius Apho. 20. Those Accidents which doe arise from the influence
of the Planets and Starres from generall constitutions, are not one accident onely, or of one nature and quality, but many,Various Actions from this Eclips. and those various in their kinds and of manifold nature, or conditions; which is the reason why we doe dil • te so much on many general things and accidents, and not tye our selves to the old Mode of judgements, either of Junctine, Proclus, or Giuffus; Maxime illustres effectus, sunt Solis & Lunae, &c. very materiall and most famous are those eff cts which are signified by the Sun and Moone, and so we in England shall really finde by the effect, proceeding from the Eclips of which we now discourse; Sol in Anno, Luna in mense, saith Escuidus. The Sun performes his course in a year,The Sun performes his course in a year. the Moon in Moneths. So also the effects of a Solar Eclips continues for yeers, the Moone's onely Months. Those of the Sunne may continue three or foure yeares, never any longer: that petty Rabbi therefore of our own Nation who affirmed the continuance of a Solar EclipsContinuance of a Solar Eclips. might be twelve years, was very far from truth, and more ignorant he shew'd himselfe to be when he would avouch Ptolomey to maintaine his Error, whose words are, Quot horas aequinoctiales inveniemus, tot annis durabit eventus Eclipsis solaris, &c.

So many equinoctiall or equall houres as the Eclips continues, so many years the events of a Solar Eclips shall continue. So Valent. Naibod. Diff. 4. p. 357. Tempora vero magnorum eventuum non a Saturni & Jovis cōjunctionibus solumodo, sed etiam a deliquiis esse supputanda, vel hinc constare potest, quod illarum eff cta ad longissima tempora protensa, tot ipsorum & aliorum siderum per diversas Coeli regiones transitibus quasi i • finitis vicibus permutari variarique nec • ssum sit; Horum autem decreta cum biennium cum semisse nunquam▪ xcedere, queant simpliciora manent, &c.

The times when great Events sh • ll happen are not onely signified from the Conjunctions of Saturn and Jupiter, but supputated also from the Eclipses of the two Lights; or it may be inferred from hence, that the effects of the two superiors have their Portents for a long season, by reason of the so many and infi • ite transi • s of themselves and other Planets through the severall Regions of Heaven; therefore
it is necessary that their influenc • should severall times vary and change. But the effects of Eclipses doe seldome indure more then two years and a halfe.

And whereas another pretends himself • knowing in Astrologie, and affirmes, that Ptolomie saith, How many houres the Sunne is distant from the Horoscope at the time of his Eclips, so many years it will be ere the eff • cts b • gin to operate; and therefore if the Eclips be in or near the West Angle it may be twelve whole years before the effects take place. Let this Man who thinks himselfe capable of judging Astrologie, take notice that Ptolomies words are these: Sin autem erit locus d • fectus in Occidentali angulo, initia erunt tertio quadrimestri, & vehementiores effectiones in tertio triente, Ptolo. li. 2. cap. 6.

If the Eclips shall be in the seventh house or West Angle, the beginning of the effect thereby signified shall appeare in the third, fourth Month (that is, after the eighth Month) and untill the twelve Months or nine Months from the time of the Eclips; and the effects shall be more fierce in the third part of the third Month after that time, viz. about twenty Months after its beginning.

The true meaning of Ptolomey is thus; Ptolomey explained. Let there be an Eclips in the West Angle, the effects thereof shall first shew themselves in the ninth, tenth, eleventh & untill the twelfth Month after its first beginning; and twelve Months after that, or next following the end of the first twelve Months, the eff • cts shall be apparantly fierce and most operate; but in the last six Months after those foure and twenty Months or two years, the effects shall decrease and vanish; so, that no Eclips of the Sun can extend its influence longer then three years and one halfe from the houre of the Eclips,No Eclips can extend i • s effects ah • ve th • ee yeares and a halfe. nor can it be above eight or nine Months before it begin to worke. Haly Rodoan was the first that misunderstood Ptolomey, who, because it was possible that an Eclips which might fall out in the seventh House, might also be distant from the ascendant twelve houres, did unadvisedly say, it might be twelve years ere the effects of some Eclips might begin; him did Giuffus V. Is. Doctor of Naples follow in that pittifull
peece of his De Eclipsibus, and so also some of our litle knowing Astrologers, who take upon them to judge others abilities by their owne weakenesses.
Diseases portend • d from this Eclips.Let our Digression be excused; and let us examine what Diseases this Eclips is the Antecedent of.

Conjunctio Luminarium in signis Martis morbos inducit termimantes omnino ad mortem, & si fuerit in Ariete ducet infirmos extra mentem sine spe, Rigel. Apho. 84. An Eclips or Conjunction of the Luminaries in the signes belonging unto Mars, produces or is the signifier of Diseases tending unto Death; and if this Eclips be in Aries, it afflicteth the Sicke, even unto Madnesse without hopes of Recovery, viz. with Frenzies, Lethargies, Apoplexies, &c. & many other mortall Diseases do most appeare in the Head. Now by reason that this famous Eclips doth appeare in Aries, which signifies the Head, such Diseases may be greatly feared; for as Cor Gemma lib. 2. pag. 56. hath related upon a great Eclips in Aries; Nunquam tot subito morbis comitialibus apoplecticis sunt extincti. Never were so many men so suddenly destroyed by the falling Evill and Apoplecticall Diseases as in that year wherein there happened a great Eclips in Aries. Fluxiones e capite ceu manu compressis spongiis defluebant celerrimè suffocantes; augebat vehementiam mali constrictus metu sine angustia spiritus, tum sanguis ipse in vasis sensu praesentium, praeteritarum rerum memoriâ ac futurarum horrore concretus, quo nihil ad putredinem vel obstruc • ionem, atque ex consequenti ad febres pestilentes inflamationesque est efficacius.

Fluxes of rhume distilled or fell from the Head, as if they had been dropt from thence with Sponges, suffocating the afflicted Patient very suddenly. The vehemency of the evill was increased by the silent or mute spirit of feare in the sick without any torment; the Blood also in the vessels, with the sence of things present, and memory of things past and to come s • emed frozen or congealed, then which there is nothing more efficacious or effectuall to occasion rottennesse and obstruction, and so consequently Pestilentiall Feavers and inflamations.

Pestilentiae accidunt afflictâ vi Solis per aerem; Pestilentiall diseasesPestilentiall Diseases.
proceed from the ayre when the Sun his vigor or influence is restrained or afflicted; so that from the effects of the present Eclips we may fear the diseases before mentioned to be the companions or attendants of it; and the rather, for that at the time of the vernall Ingresse, the two Infortunes were angular, and in Cardinall Signs, applying to a quadrature.

Notabiliter infortunantur Planetae-per Retr • gradationem, Combustionem, Peregrinationem, Detrimentum & casum, When Planets most unfortunate. Anonimus 33. Planets are extreamly made unfortunate when they are either Retrograde, Combust, Peregrine in their Detriment or Fall: by how much the more this Aphorism is verified in our present Eclips and vernall Ingresse, by so much more the greater evils may be expected.

In the vernall Ingresse Saturn was Peregrine, in his Detriment, and Stationary, towards his Direction; as if he stood still and studied how to punish Man-kind. In the Figure of our Eclips we have Mars in his Detriment, and Peregrine; from hence we may expect one mischief in the neck of another, as also, all manner of Saturnine and Martiall Diseases, and they generall and very grievous in all or most Provinces and Countries; I mean these Diseases by them signified, will much afflict the poor Commonalty: for Pessima erit elementorum & populi constitutio, quando Saturnus & Mars infortunati, occupaverint Angulos, cadant vero fortunae: Its the worst constitution of Heaven, or of the Elements that may be, for the People or Man-kind in generall, when Saturn and Mars being unfortunate doe occupy the Angles, and the two Fortunes be cadent: In the vernall Ingresse Saturn and Mars occupied the tenth house and seventh, Venus was afflicted both by Saturn and Mars, Jupiter was then Peregrine and cadent in the third: But we are to examine our Figure, and see neer unto what time these accidents or Sicknesses may appear.

Cum Almuten Eclipsis vel Conjunctionis magnae pervenerit ad signa Angularia; & Eclipsis & magnae Conjunctionis accident effec • us significati, &c. When the Almuten of an Eclips or great
Conjunction shall transit, or by motion passe through those Signs which possessed the four Angles at the time of the great Conjunction or Eclips, then the effects signified either from the Eclips or Conjunction shall manifest themselves. The Signs which were angular in 1642/3 in the conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter were Scorpio and Taurus, the last two degrees of Sagittary and Gemini, all Capricorn and Cancer.

The Angles of the Scheam in this Eclips are Pisces, Virgo, Cancer and Capricorn; Saturn for these three yeers last past hath transited Cancer, the Sign Angular in the great Conjunction, and Jupiter Capricorn; and from hence hath Scotland, Holland and Amsterdam suffered, the Portugall from the ill disposition of Jupiter, as well as the common Law of England, Remarkable Times. and whole Priesthood of our Nation, many of them very, very, very deservedly. About the second week in July 1652. Mars transits the Ascendant of this Eclips, and the second week in October 1652. the cusp of the fourth House; the first and second dayes of January 1653. he transits the degree culminating at the Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter: In October 1653. about the twelfth, thirteenth, fourteenth and fifteenth dayss, he transits the fifteenth and sixteenth of Capricorn, viz. the Angle of the seventh; and the 31. of December 1653. and the first, second and third of January 1654. he transits the degrees now culminating, viz. the fifteenth of Pisces: Saturn in regard of his slow motion, comes not to any of the Angles of the Eclipse, onely in 1653. and latter end of August, he transits the nineteenth and twentieth degree of Leo, in perfect trine to the place eclipsed. Neer upon those times will very materiall and grand Accidents happen, and great distactions in publike Consulta • ions about March 1653. by reason of the Opposition of Saturn and Jupiter in Leo and Aquarius, Accidents in 1653. two fixed Signs: After which (fiunt strages) as Cardan, Seg. 5. Aph. 49. viz. after the Opposition of Saturn and Jupiter, many times succeeds great slaughters,Two things Principally intended. yea many times cutting to the very ground great Families, Cities and Countries. And indeed two things seem to me principally to be intended
from this Eclips, according to that of Cardan, Seg. 2. Apho. 17. Considerare oportet tempore Eclipsis vires Planetae dominantis; The Generall accidents of this Eclips. nam non Eclipsis, sed illius significatio apparebit: Consider the strength of the planet who governs the place Eclipsed; not the Eclips, but what he signifies shall appear, Mars governes the degree and signe Eclipsed, but Ʋenus is the strongest planet in the figure: After famine, the sword and pestilence haue done their parts, I see much good towards Ireland; from hence I inferr that one thing principally intended is Famin or il Harvests, Dropsicall diseases vulgarly, Tumults & seditions, slaughter at Sea, Sea fights, Shipwracks, the small Pox in abundance, Murrain or sicknesse in great Cattle, after that the Plague,The Common wealth of England exalted from influence of this Eclips. irruption of the Seas or waters in many places. The second thing herein intended doth seem to me to be; The rise or growth of the Common-wealth of England to a very high esteem all over the world: for Confirmation of this my judgement, Let me be heard according unto my owne principles, and not judged without hearing, either by Tbomas Wiseaker, or any of the Priestbytery according to their unseemly Commentary or stupid Annotations on the 10. of Jeremiah and verse the 2. Qui Bavium non odit: Let him read that puddle of Envy and Nonsence.

First, it is acknowledged by all except madmen; that Sol omnibus planetis tribuit vires. Card. Seg. 5. Apho. 171. The Sun gives vertue to all the planets and in Apho. 156. Solis vis est calefacere & producere: the influence of the Sun doth heate and produce life▪ and Being to every M • n and Plant and Creature, and as we have said before in this discourse, the works or influence of the S • n are the most glorious and manifest, &c. From hence is it possible to be inferred we shall give Laws and Bounds to the ambitious Hollander & crack-braind French: The English to give Lawes to the Hollander.
Aries we know hath been acknowledged by al Astrologers to be the ascendant sign of England, & the English in their manners subject to the Condition of that Signe, and Mars who is Lord of the signe. Magis autem naturam Arietis & Martis referunt Britania, Germania &c. Ptol: Lib. 2. Pag. 77. quare in his regionibus magna ex parte homines sunt magis feri & truces. Brittain
and Germany do rather follow the nature of Aries and Mars;
Aries & Mars for the English. therefore in these Regions for the greater part the men are very fierce and valiant. In this signe and in the Degree of his exaltation is the Sun at this present, neare unto the Dragons head; at the beginning of the Eclips Aries arising towards the Meridian and in the Conclusion or at the end of it the same signe Aries Culminating. Some memorable thing therefore tending unto Honour and greatnesse, or unto glory and Renown must of necessity be signified to happen unto the Common-wealth of England, but a dissipation or subversion of many men now in Authority, Sol omnium fortunarum maxima est, neque planeta ullus magis beneficus. Of all the planets the Sun is the greatest fortune, nor is any planet so beneficiall or bountifull unto Mankind; therefore he being in the degree of his Exaltation and possessing Englands Horoscopicall signe is friend unto our Nation, and will make our Renowne to flourish all over the world. Faxit Deus. Pugno pro patria.

The signe wherin this Eclips at present is in, is Aries viz. Bestiall;Rot of Sheepe and Cattle. wherein Mars Lord of the Eclipseis placed, in Taurus, and are both bestiall; therefore we may feare a Rot of Sheep and some malevolent and pestilentiall sicknesse unto our great Cattle, viz. Horse, Cowes, Oxen, &c.

q.l: At, cum sub formis hominum latitabit Apollo;
Sub brutis formis, brutorum corpora laedet,
Ac segetes, fructusque soli, frumenta, pecusque;
Paucis, quidquid erit, signi monstrabit imago.

div.p: The Sun so oft as he is Eclipsed in humane signes, which have representation of Men, doth shew sicknesse and other plagues unto men; when he is obscured in brute signs or such as represent Cattle, he threatens the bodyes of Cattle or beasts of all kinds, Corne and Fruits of the earth in every kind &c. Mizaldus. De eclipsibus.

This our judgement is approved by Escuidus, fol. 21. Diff. 1. Inquiremus quae sunt figurae signorum in quibus erit eclipsis & in
quibus erunt stellae gubernatrices, &c. Si figurae signorum sunt similes figuris animalium, erunt accidentia in quadrupedibus. Let us inquire what are the formes or figures of the signes wherein the Eclipses are,Foems of the Signs wherin the Eclipses are. and wherein the Dominators or Rulers are; if the formes or signes be alike unto the bestiall Creature, the damages which the Eclips doth portend shall fall upon four footed beasts, &c.

Eclipsis Solis cum fuerit in Ariete, significabit interitum Regum & divitum, & siccitatem, sive terrae sterilitatem, atque famem. Messahalah Cap. 7: de eclipsi solis. An Eclips of the Sun in Aries portends death to Kings, Richmen, drinesse,Barrennesse, Famine. barrennesse of the Earth, Famine, &c. Et si fuerit in signo aequinoctij vernalis erit in fructbus arborum, cum oriri coeperint & in aliis quae nascuntur in Ʋere. If it be in Aries in or neare the Equinox, his signification will extend to fruits growing on trees when they first shew themselves, &c.

Whereas I find a generall feare possessing mens spirits,Caution to the Nation not to fear. concerning the darknesse which the Eclips portends, and some queries whether it threatens not danger unto those people who are either in the Fields about their labouring occasions, or other wayes occupied without dores on their Domesticall affaires; I fay it threatens no Man or Cattle with danger in that consideration; nor will the Darknesse it selfe be of so great or long a continuance as many imagine; about halfe an hour after nine in the morning▪ on Munday on the twenty ninth day of March will be the greatest darknesse, if the ayre be serene and cleare,When the greatest • arknesse will be. which in some measure I feare by the arising of Saturn neare that time, and the Moon her application unto his Quadratures; however, there is no danger at all to any that shall be the Spectators of it; the darknesse it selfe will not last hardly one quarter of an houre; I mean its greatest obscurity will last little longer; yet I beleeve such and so great it will be for the time that we shall behold the fixed starrs,Very like to see the fixed Star. as also Mars and Ʋenus who are at that time South East, Ʋenus being more Easterly then Mars.

Solares autem Eclipses nec magnitudinis quidem • ratione, eodem
modo vbique apparent: Lumen enin solare quamvis defecerit, cito tamen restituitur. Proclus, in Paraphras. Lib. 2.: Ptol. Pag. 65. Although the Light of the Sun be eclipsed or darkned,The Sunne quickly recovers his light. yet it quickly recovers it selfe; Now if we will know what manner of man or men he or they must be, who are either already borne and shall occasion so great changes in every Nation, or who they shall be hereafter who shall first manifest their Actions, we must conclude them or those men have either Aries Leo or Sagittarius the Ascendant or Ascendants of their Nativities, or to culminate in their tenth house and to have great relation and Concurrence either with the first Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter in 1603. or with their second Conjunction in 1623. & to have either the Sun and Moon in Regall signs or in reception with the superiors,What signe shall ascend in their Nativities who shall do wonders. and they or one of them in Regall signes, or else borne in or neare the houre of some eminent Eclips: Qui autem nattus fuerit hora Eclipsis, maximè si potentis viri filius fuerit, multitudinum hominum causa erit mortis. Seg. 4. Aphor. 97. He who is borne in the houre or time of an Eclips • , if he be the son of some eminent man of the nation, shall occasion the death of a multitude of men by partaking with him ere he acquire a Kingdome or Government. For Ad regnum adipiscendum, ex tribus duo semper necessaria sunt, conjunctio familiae cum successione, bonum aliquod in genitura, & ejus convenientia cum regno. Two things of three are requisite ever in that man who desires to obtain a Kingdome, viz. relation of his family to the succession, some great matter in his nativity, and the conveniency or concordance of that nativity with the Kingdome.

For it is very true which Cardan delivers in his Seg. 7. and Aphoris. 166. Geniturae validae regna mutant; debiles autem ab illis immutantur & fortunam illorum sequuntur, &c. validas autem dico etiam quae malis potentibus subjiciuntur. Strong Genitures or men who have strong Nativityes do make Changes or overturn Kingdomes and Common wealths; but they who have weake Nativityes or the planets in their Nativityes weake, are overcome or overborne by the former and follow the
fortune of the Victors; I call those also powerfull and well fortified Nativityes in whose Genitures the infortunes bcing very strong have most dominion; of this did we make excellent use in our Annual Judgements 1644. 1645. and do very well remember that at what time and as oft as Ʋenus did transit the tenth or twelveth degrees of Taurus, King Charles had ever some memorable successe against the Parlament, those degrees Culminating in his Nativity; and we all remember that whilst Saturn was in Ari • s which was part of 1643. 1644. and 1645. the whole Nation of Englishmen groaned under a most heavy War; but in or about the lattter end of May 1645. when Saturn got out of Aries into Taurus, our happinesse began to appeare by that memorable overthrow of the Kings forces at Naseby in Northamptonshiere the 14. of June, after which we did nothing▪ but Rout and runn after,Note. and overcome our enemyes. One thing more is observable, that the very 2 of Sept. 1644. Saturn was in Aries, and what is almost miraculous, in the very same degree and but some few minutes excepted, wherein this very memorable Eclips of the Sun now is: Saturn was then in 19. deg. 45. of Aries; the Sun now in 19 deg. and 15. of Aries. There is no earthly things comes to passe without Providence, and an orderly Regulation of Nature by the Command and permission of the great God of Nature; I shall from this strange Antipathy onely conclude, That accordingly as in 1644. Saturn being then in our degree Eclipsed,Parlament promised well if they prevent the Dutch treachery. did then shew our greatest affliction or the greatest Dishonour and Losse this present Parlament have received by the routing and losse of the Earl of Essex his Army in Cornwall: so I am now as confident the Sun illustrating that degre of Aries, that our present Common wealnh of England shall have such Honour and successe in all their negotiations and undertakings of as great concernment for the utility, benefit and happinesse of this Nation, as that sad accident was of sorrow unto them who then sat at the stern, and unto all us little people of meaner quality. Yet there is a Person of the greatest vertue and Honour of our English Nation, that can well remember, I told him,
after the 10. or 12. of June 1645; the King would no more thrive, &c. What are the true Genitures of either the valiant Lord Fairfax or any other since of all our Generall Officers, I doe not perfectly know, yet some I doe, and these have Nativityes exactly contradictory to the late Kings: it's enough that the degree of the last Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter is in the cuspe of the seventh house in the Nativity of one expecting to be a great man, but must not; some may be so Criticall as to demand when shall these things by us spoken come to passe,When the accidents shall come to passe. or whether all on a suddaine, and in every Region at or neare the same time? unto that I answer: Climatum differentia facit ut celerius aut tardius eventus proveniant. The difference of Climates occasions that the effects of Eclipses do sooner come to effect in one Country, and later in another; for neither doth the Sun rise in every Kingdome at one houre. Somewhat will be expected we should say, concerning those on whose Nativityes any of these Eclipses may have concernment, and they are onely those, who have either the Sun or Moon in the 6. degree of Aries or Libra or 6. degr. of Cancer or Capricorn, according to the first Eclips of the Moon in March.

Who concerned in the Eclipses.They are concerned in the influence of the great Eclips of the Sun, who have either the nineteenth or twentieth of Aries, or of Libra, or of Cancer or Capricorn, the place of their Sun or Moon at the time of their Births.

They are concerned in the operation of the second Eclips of the Moon, who have either the Sun or Moon Ascendant or Mid heaven in the 25. degr. of Pisces, Virgo, Sagittarius or Gemini; wherein the King of Scotland may claim the greatest share in the effects of the last Lunar Eclips, &c.

The King of Spain King of Spain. hath the Sun in his Nativity in 19. d. of Aries (if I am rightly informed) and the Dragons tail there also; happy may he be, if he, I say he himself, escape either blindnesse, or some hurt to one of his Eyes, or some sad fate (if not death) ere the influence of this Eclips determine, let him beware of fire, powder, treason, or hot Feavers: he is like to be much concerned either in himself
or Children (if he have any) from this dire influence, &c.

Many I know wlll be apt to misapply our words, and to conceive we intend the influence of this Eclips to fall generally over or upon every Nation of Europe; these men seem to know nothing; for nulla Eclipsis omnino toti orbi penuriam au • pestem pronunciare potest; pestis autem ex his, nunquam quatuor annis durare potest, Cardanus,When we may expecta terrible Plague. Seg. 7. Apho. 121. No Eclips can signifie penury or scarcity, or a Pestilence to be generall unto the whole World; for a Pestilence or Plague derived from the influence of an Eclips either Solar or Lunar, cannot last above four yeers, &c. but we have no such generall Calamity now threatned upon England; let such a thing be expected from the effects of the Eclips in 1654. at what time Saturn is got into the fiery Sign Leo, and not far removed from the Luminaries in the Eclips.

For although it be most true, that the Planet who disposeth of the place of the Eclips, shall mostly shew what manner or quality the effects shall be of, yet are they more or lesse, great or little, more forcible, or more restrained, according to the quality of that Planets existence and fortitude at time of the Eclips. Mars disposeth the Eclips; what he signifieth, see in our method of Eclipses following, &c.

Stellae quae disponunt Eclipsium loca, si noviter emergunt aut occultantur, aut stationem ingrediuntur, vel noctu emicant, augent vel minuunt effectus: Augent quidem dum é Solis radiis emergunt & in stationibus sunt; etsi enim debiliores sint, quia tamen firmi manent in uno loco plus operantur; debilis enim assiduè assistens plus operatur, quam validus vagans: Minuunt vero effectus cum occultantur Planetae dispositores & noctu emicantes & retrogradi. Dasipodius Apho. 76.

Those Stars or Planets which dispose of the places or degrees of the Eclips, if they doe either newly separate from the Sun beams, or appear before them, or are obscur'd or clouded by them, or they enter their station, or shine in the night, doe either encrease or dimi • ish the effects: they verily doe encrease the effects of the influence whilest they are hastening from the Sun beams, and are in their stations; for not
although they then appear to be more weak, yet because they remain firm in one place (this is understood by a stationary Planet) they more effectually send down their influence; for a weak Planet being ever at work, doth more strongly operate then a stronger Planet, who is w • ndring in motion, and not at all fixed; for Planets who are Dispositors of Eclipses,Planets weak when under the earth. when they are obscured by the Sun beams, are of lesse effect, as also when they are Retrograde, and shine in the night, viz. are seen after the Sun set; for you must know, the vertues of all Planets are extreamly weakned when their bodies are subterranean.

We shall draw unto a conclusion, affirming that about June, Effects begin aboet August 1652. July, August and September next, there will be an appearance of some memorable actions, which in part will declare a beginning of many others to succeed in the like kind, probably Eastward, towards March, April and May 1653. and so following; or neer those three Moneths, the Eclips its effects will begin to be in their fullest vigour and glory, but much in Consultations or Treaties; and towards September, October and Novemb. 1653. a little begin to lessen: Certainly it is the fore-runner of the eclipsing or diminishing of the Glory, Majesty and Dominion of many men now in present Authority, both in England our own Nation, and also the Netherlands, Spain and France, which miserable and divided Country I pitty; yet France must be invaded, and the King thereof become most unfortunate.

The time of the events signified by this Eclips, ending a little after that time which this present Parlament seems to have voted to give a period to their sitting; it is therefore very probably to be gathered from the effects of this Eclips, that in good earnest the Souldier and People will joyn in one for calling a New Representative New Representative. in this Commonwealth: for the Moon, who signifieth the People, eclipseth the Sun; as if nothing would satisfie our earnest desires but that which perhaps it had been better for us to decline, it being more easie to repair an old house, then build a new.

Now forasmuch as the Sun hath representation of the Commonwealths Treasurer and Treasury, being Lord of the second house, this Eclips doth admonish all such as have had fingering in the Treasure of the Commonwealth, to prepare their Accompts; for their day of judgement is coming; and very great reason it should, for if Vox Populi be Vox Dei, it is generally conceived there is privately detained in severall Treasurers hands,Treasurers must accompt and in such as have been Collectors for this State, more mony then would pay the Army one yeers wages.

Our State endeavour by their prudent Commissioners in Scotland to settle that Nation; I doe perceive by this Eclips whatever the best of the Scots promise, falshood is intended, Scots very fals and private Conspiracies will be managed betwixt many of the People and Priests, for outing us in those parts, they having no eyes to see their happinesse by Union with us; how great a misfortune therefore it is, any People may fee by this onely act of theirs, to see with no other eyes but those of the Clergy, many whereof are tenebrous, and very few clear without spots, viz. in their understandings and crazy Noddles: The influence of this Eclips will deprave mens tempers, or the constitutions of mens Bodies,Ayre corrupted. so far as they have connexion with the Elements, by reason the Ayre in many places will be infected with grosse vapours, and unwholsome sudden blasts of Wind, tempestuous and unprofitable. The Autumns of these two yeers I much fear will be unhealthy, & People apt to surfet or create Maladies in their Stomacks, &c. from those infections; Agues, Dropsies, Tympanies, more then vulgar will appear; but who it is shall suffer this fate following, I leave to times discovery:
Sublatus fortè veneno,Sudden death to some great man, by stabbing, or the like.
Aut caesus gladio, subita vel morte vocatus.
We will conclude this Treatise with our own Astrologicall Judgement of this yeer 1652. delivered by us, and printed 1644. in our Propheticall Merlin, pag. 115.
Strange Apparitions, and unusuall sights in the Southeast parts.
A yeer full of Embassages.
A preparative in the Heavens for a great Plague.
Florentines make Tumults.
Italy is fearfull. Wars in Bohemia. Ʋproars in Rome.
Scotland beware a Famine. ENGLAND be thou Content.
Also in page 110. we say;
Wo to a great Family of EVROPE, that was, is now, but shall be no more, &c.

We conclude with these Verses of Chrysippus:
Quam falsò accusant superos, stultique queruntur
Mortales! etenim nostrorum causa malorum
Ipsi nos sumus & sua quemque vecordia laedit.

div.head:
The MOON Eclipsed, September 7th. 1653.
astrological chart
div.p:
NOthing is more memorable in this Lunar Eclips then that the degree eclipsed was the true place of the last Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter 1642/3. and as that Conjunction was celebrated in the second house, intimat ng the infinite trouble that some men should have to preserve • heir Estates, who were of such Families, or descended ••• m such as had any relation to Saturn at the time of their Fam lies
first erection; so also it did declare the sudden & unexpected preferment of some other Families, who had their originall preferment, or first greatnesse under either Sagittarius or Pisces: Now this Lunar Eclips beginning in the Ascendant, and passing through the twelfth house, the Dispositor of the Eclips being Jupiter, weak and in his Fall, it imports the great difficulties severall of those then, and since, eminent Men, shall goe thorough to preserve that Estate and Honour they have since 1642. acquired; not without much affliction of mind shall they now preserve that Honour or esteem they have so long enjoyed; a secret hand of P • licy, or a repining People, either by cunning or violence, dispossessing them of part of their Estates, and all or most of their Honour: jam seges est.

This Eclips seems to me to be the Messenger or Antecedent of corrupt ayre, unwholsome W • ather, infecting the generality of People with abundance of corrupt Humours, thereby preparing matter for those pestilentiall Diseases approaching.

This Eclips beginning in the Ascendant, begins very soon to operate, viz. according to our method and Ptolomey's, within three moneths after its beginning, and ends about the middle of December following: its the Significator of Sea fights, or dammage to Ships, Sailors, Fisher-men; of some peremptory requests in the Presbyt • ry, or some secret Consultations of theirs, for their advancement or re-establishment; of the imprisonment of some dis-affected people to our Commonwealth, of distraction in or about the Law, or Courts of Justice; much unwillingnesse of the Commonalty to contribute to their Ministers: some treasonable designs in action or Councell against the Magistracy; hopes and desires in the Ministers to subject the Parlament to their Lawes.

Many disasters in the West Indies, great losse unto the Portingall; famine and scarcity approaching in Italy; sad news from the East Indies; sudden Commotions in Paris, or in many parts of France; a very troublesome and unquiet Autumn;
many State officers in question ubicunque; many in Authority in great fear and tribulation; abundance of Sicknesses, as Agues, Tumors and Gouts, small Pocks, Lethargies, Palpitation of the Heart, black Jaundies, Cholick, torment in the Guts, many Women miscarrying through fear and frights; a sad time with the Dutch in many places of the World; no good time for the King or Governours of Spain and his Territories.

Signa Communia in homines, Reges Magistratus, Dasipod. 69. When Eclipses are in common Signs, the influence hath most effect on men, Kings, Magistrates. The Eclips is in partill opposition unto the degree ascending of the King of Scots; Pernitiosior est ea Eclipsis quae accidet in Horoscopo, geniturarumque quae in ortivo annuarum conversionum Cardine; portenditur enim nato illi malum aliquod exitiosum in corpore ejus vitalique substantia: Thus saith Junctine, in Tractatu de Eclip. pag. 307.

That Eclips is more dangerous or pernitious which shall be in the Horoscope or Ascendant of the birth; or which shall be in the degree Ascending in an Annuall Revolution: it portends unto the Native some ominous and mischievous action as unto his body and also in his vitall substance; Perhaps he shall be deprived of his French Pension. We shall Conclude with one observation more of the said Junctine who further saith;

Loca eclipsium aut opposita, nodusque Meridianus si acciderint in Horoscopo natalitij thematis, aut locis luminarium, praecipuè conditionarij, natus ille cujus fuerit genitura, in maximis vitae versabitur periculis, quae magna cum difficultate evitari poterunt: imo è vita discedet, si anni illius Rex, & Horoscopi dominus & divisor in utroque themate, natalis scilicet & revolutionis fuerint malè affecti, &c. 307.

Either the Degrees Eclipsed or their opposits, and the South N • de, if these happen in the Ascendant of the Radix of any one in his nativity, or especially the Luminarie of the time, he whose Nativity that shall be, shall be plunged with many misfortunes and casualtyes in his life, which cannot be avoyded with • ut great difficulty: nay, if the Lord of the Ascendant of that yeare when the Eclips is, and
the Divisor of the profectionall figure and the Lord of the radicall figure be ill-affected, then it may be much feared he will be in danger of Death: The continuance of this Eclips is about 3 hours and 20. minut • s: and therfore the Events shall expresse themselves three whole moneths and lesse then a halfe moneth, or about three moneths and twenty dayes, &c.

If any desire to veiw those Quadrangles of the signes unto which the Kingdomes, Nations, Cities or Countries of Europe which are like to be passive in the effects of this Eclips, are subject unto; Let them peruse Master Bookers Almanack of 1652.

div.head: Astrologicall Aphorismes.
div.p: HE who is naturally well affected unto Astrology shall verily pronounce more certain Judgements.

2 Divers effects of the Starrs are drawnforth of the Starrs, according to the various dispositions of the matter: whereof the Astrologer ought very well to examine the severall natures and qualityes of the Subjects receiving.
3 Because alwayes matter determines the form, it comes to passe that we doe freely by our wicked operations conceive our Starrs to produce those Detriments unto us.

4 The formes wherewith the Heavenly bodies do operate, are called Images, unto which the formes inferiour are subject: these are many in the signes, Decanates, and Degrees, in some Stars, they are seperate and in many joyn'd together.

5 The visible or sensible Images of the 8th Sphear are very many, and many are made dayly there by the Planets: all which ought to be considered of the Astrologer: they have all great efficacy upon inferior bodies.
6 A Figure is not active (as some Platonists say) but the form, wherein the substance operates.
7 When he who consults produceth the Sigillation of his Constellation moving him thereunto, how sufficiently then may • st thou then resolve that matter propounded.
8 The signes have their Heterogeniall parts of the Element and answering to the Heaven, which we call the Termes of the 5 Planets.
9 Because Images, and inferior mutations, are subject to inferiors, therefore we must prudently by similitude and Analogy search out the Actions and significations of the Heavenly bodies.
10 The parts of our body are Heterogeniall, and therefore according to their proper temperaments are subject to divers Planets.
11 The significations of things are threefold, na • urall, accidentall and speciall; the speciall are first to be inquired, next the accidentall, after that, the Naturall.
12 Sol and Mars are fiery; the heat of Mars is d • structive, that of the Sun answers the vivifying heavenly fire.
13 Mercury is hot, cold, dry and moist in the frrst degree, as some will have it; but he hath an indifferent and Convertible nature.

14 Venus is cold in the second degree, moyst in the third; the Moon is cold in the third degree, moyst in the fourth Jupiter is hot in the second degree, moyst in the first; the Sun is hot in the third degree dry in the second. Mars is dry in the third, hot in the fourth. Saturn is cold and dry in the fourth degree.
15 The superior Planets are most essicacious; the inferior are weake, and easily do suffer by the superiors, and receive either good or ill from them.
16 Superior Planets because they much resist, they doe not easily receive a detriment, or good turn from the inferior Planets.
17 The misfortunes proceeding from Saturn and Mars are mitigated if their places are protected by Jupiter, being well disposed and in good aspect.
18 When a Planet who is a fortune, is in Conjunction with an infortune, he allayes his malice, so that the infortune shall do no hurt.
19 The fixed Stars are the most efficacious of all in their operations; for what actions they manifest or occasion are very great.
20 The fixed Stars doe imitate the nature and action of the Erraticals or Planets; wherefore they transfer their actions unto them.
21 The Moon hath a certaine naturall mutability, therefore she easily communicates unto us the influence of other Stars.
22 The Moon doth then most especially transfer Actions unto the inferior World, and the influx of other Stars from whom she is seperated, when she is swift in motion.
23 Three manner of wayes the Planets are varied or changed, by reason of their first qualities of their houses and significations.
24 Saturn governs Contemplation and Memory: Mars Boldnes and fortitude, if they want not strength, or are ill disposed.
25 Retrograde Planets degenerate from their proper nature, by that meanes Fortunes are made infortunes, and the evill Planets farre worse.
26 Planets do manifest greater and worser evils when they are Stationary, then when Retrograde.
27 The Reception of Planets when they behold one another, if it be strong, doth diminish the malice of an evill aspect, and increases the goodnesse of a good aspect.
28 A Planet in an Angle doth more effectually produce his effects, but remisse in cadent houses.
29 Be not too confident either of a sextill or trine aspect in violent Signes, nor out of those Signes in which the Planets behold one another, yet essentially suffer.
30 Consider what things the Planets perform not by their aspects, and observe if they doe them not by their Antiscions; for the Antiscions have power, and are to be enumerated amongst aspects.
31 Its rare if any Planet prove a fortune in the eight or twelfth, by reason of the malignancy of those houses.
32 The qualities of Saturn and Mars are not made better by their conjunction: being mixed so together they are confounded, and hurt very much.
33 Planets are notably made unfortunate by these Accidents, viz. Combustion, Retrogradation, Peregrination, Detriment and fall.
34 The swift and various motions of the Planets are to be considered, as also their slownesse; because when they vary, the accidents of the aspects doe alter.
35 Saturn seldome applies to any Planet, by reason whereof he signifies great Princes and firme Monarchs.
36 A partill Aspect comes to passe within the difference of three degrees, a platicke Aspect happens by a semediameter of the Orbs of the Planets.
37 The vertue of a Planet is in that House, whose beginning or Cuspe a Planet precedes by no greater space then five degrees.
31 Vnderstand the simple qualityes of the Planets for from thence thou shalt know all their mixt significations.
39 Those houses which behold not the Ascendant, signifie occult or obscu • e places, and these houses are the 12: 8. and 6.
40 The application of Planets shews what is to come, the seperation what is past.

FOr the great satisfaction I have my self received thereby, and the excellent Divinity therein contained, Sold by Giles Calvert. I thought fit to commend unto thee this ensuing Book, called The late Assembly of Divines Confession of Faith examined: wherein many of their Excesses and Defects, of their Confusions and Disorders, of their Errors and Contradictions, are presented, &c. by a modest, but admirable sound Pen-man. It's apparent by this Treatise, there were many good Divines in England, besides those present in the Assembly.

There is also now published, Theatrum Chemicum
Britannicum, containing severall Poeticall pieces of our famous English Philosophers, who have written the Hermetique Mysteries, or of the Philosophers Stone, in the English Tongue; published in honour of the English Nation, by Elias Ashmole, Esq; a Gentleman very learned, and a great lover of Antiquities. The Collection it self is of excellent Learning, and the Publishers Annotations on some hard places most ingeniously and profoundly performed.
Rothmans Chiromancy, or, the Harmony of Chir • mancy with Astrology; Englished by Capt. George Wharton: sold by Nathaniel Brooks. A piece of acurate Learning.

There will be publique in Easter Term next, an excellent piece of Chiromancy and Metaposcopy, viz. rationall Judgement from the lines of the Forehad, by Richard Sanders, Student in Astrology. The like Work never extant in English. All sold by Nathaniel Brooks at the Angel in Cornhill.

The Darknesse of Atheism dispelled by the Light of Nature: A learned and elaborate Treatise; is newly published, written by Doctor Charleton, Physitian to the late King. London, Printed for W. Lee at the Turks head in Fleet-street, 1652.
